loans.name: Nowerinah's Group

texts.en: B. Nowerinah is a hard working and friendly lady and the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a business lady with a retail shop in Senyi that she has been running for 8 years. Although there is a lot of competition, she is able to make a good weekly profit. Nowerinah is a married lady with 7 children ranging between the ages of 8 to 24 years; she also takes care of orphans. She is grateful for her loans that enable her to have quality products on her shelves and, therefore, more customers. She has a dream of becoming a wholesaler as well as educating her children to the highest level of learning. Nowerinah needs a loan to help restock her shop with more goods, since this allows for a steady supply of products. She hopes to be able to use the funds towards the payment of her children’s school fees.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more items.

loans.name: Winifred

texts.en:
Winifred sells foodstuffs and has a pig farming business in order to earn a living. She is married with two children. They live in Ntabesi-Nkwen, Cameroon. Winifred and her entire family are living in a house with four rooms. Winifred has had to overcome some challenges in life such as ill health. She has faced difficulties paying her children's school fees.

This will be Winifred’s fourth loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2005, and she has been quite successful in the past with her business, due to a good location and her reasonable prices. Also, with experience, she is now getting good profits from her business. Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children, buy necessities for the family and give them good medication whenever they are sick. The rest she will plough back into her business.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy garri, yams, beans, corn and piglets

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is forty-three years old. She is married and has three children, all of whom attend school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in the town of Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works hard to help her husband provide for the family. 

Lucy is a trader. She runs a drug store by the roadside in her community. She buys the drugs from vans that distribute them in her area. She has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy all kinds of drugs to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy drugs for her drug store

loans.name: Confidence

texts.en:
Confidence is 48 years old. She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in the town of Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works hard to help her husband provide for their family. 

Confidence sells printed textile fabrics. She hawks (sells door-to-door) in her community. Confidence also sells charcoal. She buys the textiles in nearby towns. Confidence has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk so she can expand her business.

loans.use: To buy fabrics to sell

loans.name: Papa Alassane

texts.fr: M. Papa Alassane D. a seulement 30 ans, mais il a 20 ans d'expérience dans son secteur primaire: l'élevage poussins.  Il a commencé le travail très jeune, grace à son pere, qui l'a initié dans le metier.  Sur le toit de son appartement, M. D. a construit une poulaillier pour les poussins (derrière de M. D. dans le photo).  Avec le crédit et son propre fonds, Il veut acheter 1000 poussins et 50 grands sacs d'alimentation pour bien nourrir les poussins.  M. D. est un membre d'UIMCEC depuis 2003, est il a reçu 6 prêts antérieurs pour ses activités.  Il habite a Yoff, Dakar avec sa femme et six petits enfants.
texts.en:
Mr. Papa Alassane D. is only 30 years old, but he has 20 years of experience in his primary sector: raising chicks. He started working at a very young age, thanks to his father, who introduced him to the trade. On the roof of his apartment, he built a coop for the chicks (behind Mr. D. in the photo). With the loan and his own funds, he wants to buy 1,000 chicks and 50 large sacks of food to feed them well. Mr. D. has been a member of UIMCEC since 2003. He has received six previous loans for his businesses. He lives in Yoff, Dakar, with his wife and six small children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chicks

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a 42-year-old married mother of eight children, some of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Kade, a farming and commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. 

Gladys sells second-hand clothes. She hawks (sells door-to-door) in her community and also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Gladys buys bales of second-hand textiles from nearby towns. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bales of clothes

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr: Madame B. est une entrepreneur à Grand Yoff, Dakar.  Elle vend des sachets de jus de fruits (très délicieuses) aux détaillants qui les revendent ambulante ou dans le marchés.  Elle va l'utiliser le crédit de 100.000 CFCA pour acheter une nouvelle machine pour le collage de sachets et aussi remplir son stock des ingrédients.  Son mari est le soutien de famille, mais avec sa petite entreprise, Madame B. peut contribuer aux finances de famille.
texts.en:
Ms. B. is an entrepreneur in Grand Yoff, Dakar. She sells pouches of fruit juice (very delicious) to the retailers who resell them door-to-door or at marketplaces. She is going to use the loan of 100,000 francs CFA to buy a new machine for pouch bonding and also for replenishing her stock of ingredients. Her husband is the breadwinner, but with her small enterprise, Ms. B. can contribute to family finances.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a machine for bonding the pouches

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa is a 42-year-old married mother of three children, all of whom attend school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in the town of Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town, but the majority of the residents practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation alongside other trading activities. 

Theresa prepares and sells porridge in the mornings. Theresa hawks (sells door-to-door) in her community. She buys the goods from nearby communities. She has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy maize for her porridge business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a 42-year-old married mother of six children, all of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in the town of Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town, but the majority of the inhabitants practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation along with other trading activities. 

Janet sells maize and other food. She buys the goods from nearby communities. Janet sells at the local market and treks to markets farther away. She has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk so she can expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize to sell

loans.name: Kyakuwa Group

texts.en: N. Harriet is the leader and founding member of her group in Senyi. She is a friendly and hardworking woman, a wife, and the mother of six children. She cares for her children as well as two children of other relatives, paying for all of their schooling. Harriet farms and sells bananas and other crops at the local market. She is requesting a loan to increase her stock of produce for resale in her market stall, and to increase production on her farm by employing the manpower needed to clear more farmland.

loans.use: To buy more produce for resale and to clear farmland.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris is a 37-year-old married young woman. Currently, she has no children and lives with her husband in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana.  Though Kade is a commercial town, the majority of people there farm either as a hobby or as a their occupation along with other trading activity. Doris is a trader in the palm oil production business. She buys fresh palm nuts in nearby communities.  Then she uses them to prepare palm oil which she supplies to retailers in her community. Doris also sells her oil at the local market and treks to sell in other communities as well. She has been in this business for three years and requests a loan in order to buy palm nuts in bulk so she can expand her business.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts in bulk.

loans.name: Joshua Anyona

texts.en: Joshua runs a retail store selling household goods such as soda, sugar, salt, and bread. He has been in this business for the last five years, but in recent years a number of new retail stores have opened in the area making for very stiff competition. Luckily, Joshua has strong customer loyalty because he has always provided good service. Besides the business challenge of increased competition, another challenge is customers not paying their debt.  In order to stay competitive, Joshua is requesting a loan of KES20,000 to buy more households goods and make his shop a one-stop solution.  In the future he would like to be a wholesaler of household goods.  Joshua describes himself as someone with a good discipline in financial management. He is married and has a one-year-old daughter.

loans.use: To buy more household goods for his retail shop.

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou N. gére une boutique d' habiles prêt à porter à Grand Yoff, Dakar.  Elle vend des habiles de la mode dans sa petite boutique.  Depuis le bas age, elle accompagnait sa mère qui faisait le commerce.  Comme beaucoup d' autres commerçants d' habiles, elle envisage une demande forte grace à la veille de la fete de Tabaski, la celebration Islamique du sacrifice.  Donc, elle voudrait renforcer ses stocks des habiles pour répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.  Madame N. a 36 ans et elle est mariée.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatou N. runs a ready-to-wear clothing store in Grand Yoff, Dakar. She sells stylish clothing in her small shop. Since she was young, she has accompanied her mother who used to work in commerce. Like many other clothing merchants, she anticipates strong demand ahead of the Tabaski Festival, the Islamic celebration of sacrifice. She would therefore like to bolster her stock of clothing to respond to the demands of her customers. Ms. N. is 36 years old and married.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her stock of ready-to-wear clothing

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is a 36-year-old married young woman with three children who all attend school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Though Kade is a commercial town, the majority of the inhabitants are into farming as a hobby or as a major occupation alongside other trading activity. Beatrice is a hairdresser by profession. She runs a salon by the roadside in her community. According to Beatrice, she has trained a number of apprentices who have set up their own salons. Beatrice has been in business for over fifteen years and requests a loan to buy artificial hair and other materials to improve her salon services.

loans.use: To buy artificial hair and other materials for her salon.

loans.name: Alioune Badara

texts.fr: M. N. est un commerçant de tissus à Grand Yoff, Dakar.  Il voudrait une crédit court-terme pour financer son activité de vente de tissus pour la veille de la fête de Tabaski.  La Tabaski est une célébration pour commémorer le sacrifice du fils d' Abraham, et marque la fin du Hadji, le pèlerinage à Mecque.  Au Sénégal, La Tabaski est une célébration très importante, donc tout le monde doit être bien habiller.  Avec le crédit de 100.000 CFCA, M. N. voudrait acheter des tissus pour répondre à cette demande élevé. Il est marié et le père d'un enfant.
texts.en:
Mr. N. sells fabric in Grand Yoff, Dakar. He would like a short term loan in order to finance his fabric retail business on the eve of the Tabaski festival. Tabaski is a celebration to commemorate the sacrifice of Abraham's son, and it marks the end of the Hajj - the pilgrimage to Mecca.

In Senegal, Tabaski is a very important celebration, thus everyone should be well dressed. With the loan of 100,000 CFCA, Mr. N. would like to buy fabric in order to meet the rising demand. He is married and the father of one child.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen his stock of fabric

loans.name: Proscovia

texts.en: Proscovia is a 40-year-old divorced mother of five children ages 16-22. None of her children attend school because they lack the school fees. Proscovia owns a two-room house where she lives with seven people because she takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. She has a stall at her home where she sells charcoal to all types of customers, both retail and wholesale. She has been in this business for five years. Proscovia works seven days a week, and receives an average of 25 customers a day.  She incurs additional transport to and from shopping from Kalerwe Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala, where she buys sacks of charcoal. Her major business challenges include thieves and the rainy season.  Her monthly expense is feeding the family. She has been with MCDT for four years and is on her eighth loan, still working with the same group mates. Proscovia joined MCDT because it was near her home and it offers loans to women as a group. Proscovia will use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal.  She wishes to grow her business enough so she can start selling only on a wholesale basis.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Malaya Group

texts.en:
Kumba F. is a leader of a group of five borrowers called Malaya. She is 63 years old and married with four children between the ages of 19 and 28. Their educational levels range from elementary drop-out through 12th grade. Kumba is illiterate due to poverty.

She and her family live on the UN Drive, a community that is a mix of both poor and middle-class Liberians in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She works on Johnson Street, which is a popular trading center where used household materials are sold. Kumba’s business is hardware. She buys hardware items like locks, nails, etc., from wholesalers and sells them on a retail basis on a table on Johnson Street in downtown Monrovia. She has been running this business for 35 years. She started with a little amount but hopes to improve to a store.

Kumba always sells new and quality goods to customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. She needs this loan to purchase more hardware items like locks, nails, hinges, etc., to improve business. Kumba dreams of building a house for her family and giving them a better future.

loans.use: To purchase more hardware items like locks, nails, hinges, etc., to improve business

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina is a 40-year-old married woman with two children, who are both in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town, though the inhabitants are into farming as a hobby or as a major occupation alongside other trading activity. 

Paulina is a trader. She trades in cosmetics in a shop in her community. Paulina has been in business for over 15 years and wants a loan to procure all kinds of cosmetics to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is 37 years old and married with two children. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. 

Sophia works to support her husband to provide for the family. Sophia is a trader. She is in the palm-oil production business. She buys the fresh palm nuts from nearby communities, prepares the oil and supplies to retailers in her community. Sophia also sells at the local market and treks as well. She has been in business for 12 years and wants a loan to procure palm nuts in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts

loans.name: Aoko Wkovele

texts.en: Aoko is the mother of a six-year-old daughter.  Her husband works as a fare collector on a public service vehicle. She sells tomatoes, onions, and cabbage in an open air market in Kakamega on a busy street.  She requests a loan of KES20,000 so she can buy more produce for resale.  Her biggest challenge is operating her business during the rainy season.  In the future, she would like to construct a larger stall and be able to sell a wider variety of vegetables. Aoko describes herself as a hardworking person.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina, is a 42-year-old married mother of two children, both still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town, however the majority of people there practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation alongside other trading activities. Faustina is a trader of maize and other food stuffs. She buys her goods from nearby communities, then treks to sell at the local market. She has been in business for over ten years and would like a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize in bulk.

loans.name: Seth

texts.en: Seth is 37 years old. He is single and has no children. He lives alone in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana and works as a taxi driver.  He transports goods and people from his community to nearby towns. Seth has been in business for three years and requests a loan to repair his taxi cab so he can stay in business. Seth also farms.

loans.use: To repair his taxi.

loans.name: We Hope To God Group

texts.en: Mariatu M., Fatmata K., Mariama M. K., Hawa J., and Falilatu J. chose an inspiring name for their newly-formed loan group, We Hope to God. These borrowers wish to expand their businesses, increase their income, and improve their standard of living thanks to a loan of 2.5 million leone (SLL) from SMT and Kiva lenders. Mariatu is the group leader. She is a 30-year-old single mother of two children, both of whom are currently enrolled in school. Mariatu has sold clothes, rubber, shoes, and other assorted goods for 5 years, and will use her share of the group loan to expand her inventory.

loans.use: Expand inventory of clothing and shoes.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is 39 years old. She is married and has three children who all attend school. She lives with her family in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Gladys is a trader who runs a provision store by the roadside in her community. She has been in this business for nineteen years and requests a loan to buy goods in bulk to increase her stock. Gladys desires to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy stock in bulk.

loans.name: Diodio

texts.fr:
Diodio N. est une dame qui habite dans la localité de Guediawaye a Daroukhane  une banlieue de Dakar.Elle évolue dans le secteur de la confection.Son activité consiste a acheter des tissus pour confectionner des draps destines a la vente.Elle est mère d’un enfant de deux ans et demi.Son mari est un commerçant immigre en Argentine.Elle capitalise une expérience de11 ans dans son activité.Généralement  elle consacre 11 h de temps par jour dans l’exercice de son activité.Apres ses études elle a eu la passion du métier de tailleur.Elle tire toute sa sa satisfaction sur le fait d’avoir maitrise son métier mais aussi sur le fait qu’il lui génère des revenus.
Ses revenus estimes actuellement a 230 000 frs peuvent être projetés a 330 000 frs après le financement.L’objet de son prêt est d’acquerir  une nouvelle machine qui viendront compléter ses quatre anciennes machines ,ce qui l’aidera a améliorer ses performances.
texts.en:
Diodio N. is a woman who lives in the town of Guediawaye in Daroukhane, a suburb of Dakar. She is in the clothing industry. Her business consists of buying fabric to fashion sheets that she resells. She is the mother of a two and half year-old child. Her husband is a retailer who immigrated to Argentina.

She capitalizes on 11 years of experience in her business. Generally, she devotes 11 hours a day to the practice of her trade. After her schooling she developed a passion for tailoring. She draws all her satisfaction from the fact that she masters her trade but also from the fact that it generates an income.

Her income, currently estimated at 230,000 FR, could be, after the financing, projected at 330,000 FR. The aim of her loan is to purchase a new sewing machine, which will complement her four old ones. This will help her to increase her performance.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a 31-year-old married mother of four children who all attend school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Margaret is a hairdresser by profession. She has a salon by the roadside in her community. She also trades in jewels. According to her, she has two apprentices. Margaret has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure artificial hair and other working materials to improve upon her services.

loans.use: To buy artificial hair for her salon.

loans.name: Alhamdulilai Group

texts.en:
This is the Alhamdulilai Group: Mariana F., Fatmata F., Kadiatu K., Rugiatu K., and Fatmata T.. The ladies sell food from stalls in their local market, and have such goods as tomatoes, onions, and hot peppers. They are seeking their first loan from Kiva and SMT, and hope that the 2.5 million Sierra Leonean leones will allow them to invest in their businesses and expand their inventory. 

Mariana is the group’s leader. She is married to an NGO (non-governmental organization) worker and has four children. With the added income coming in from her business, Mariana will be able to supplement her household’s income and improve their overall standard of living.

loans.use: Expand inventory and increase size of stand

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort, age 35, is the married mother of two children, who are both still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in the town of Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town, but the majority of its inhabitants practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation in addition to other trading activities. 

Comfort sells maize and other foods, such as yams. She buys her goods in nearby communities. Comfort sells in the local market and also treks to markets farther away. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Modern Preparatory School Of Science And Technology Group

texts.en:
The Modern Preparatory School of Science and Technology is a private school established in 2005. They have a staff of 24 serving 393 pupils. With no additional payments from the government, many of the school's teachers invest in other side-businesses -- which are usually maintained and managed by relatives or friends -- to supplement their incomes. 

Twenty-one of the professors at Modern Preparatory are seeking a loan of 16.5 million LE from SMT and Kiva lenders to invest in many of their personal businesses. Augustine G. S., a senior teacher, is the group’s leader. He has been a teacher for seven years, and is married with one young child. In addition to his teaching, Augustine owns a small business selling ready-to-wear clothing and jeans, which he would like to expand by using his share of the loan.

loans.use: To expand the inventory of his clothing shop

loans.name: Courage Group

texts.en:
Meet Kadiatu K., Abdul K., Fatmata K., Koloneh S., and Mohamed S., the members of the Courage Group. They are seeking a loan of , for 6 million LE. This will be their fifth loan as a client group of SMT. 

Kadiatu is the group leader. She is 30 years and and married, and she has two children who attend school. Kadiatu has owned her business for more years than she can remember. She sells necessary goods, such as firewood, coal pots, and other assorted cooking supplies. With her new loan, Kadiatu can expand her business inventory and increase the income she receives from her shop. She believes her additional income will allow her to become more independent of her husband and to gain authority in her household.

loans.use: To expand the inventory of her shop

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is a 62-year-old married woman with six children. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in the town of Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Rita works to help her husband to provide for their family. 

Rita produces and sells palm oil. She buys the fresh palm nuts from nearby communities, prepares the oil, and supplies to retailers in her community. She sells at the local market and treks to other communities, as well. Rita has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy palm nuts in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts

loans.name: Colombe

texts.en:
Colombe M. is 26 years old and single. She takes care of two dependent people, ages 25 and 23. She lives in Gicumbi District in the Northern Province of Rwanda,  where her office supply business is located.

Colombe has been in the office supply business for two years. A relatively recent entrepreneur, she works very hard, as is evidenced by the fact that her shop is open from 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. every day.  Her efforts are rewarded however, because she earns a monthly profit of 200,000 Rwf  (approximately US $360).

She is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders so she can purchase more and better quality inventory to sell at higher prices. This will attract new customers and help her to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy office supplies to sell

loans.name: Risper Achieng

texts.en: Risper has been selling vegetables and fruit for seven years. She sells tomatoes, oranges, onions and  kales. She is a sinlge mother with two children. She uses the proceeds from her business to take care of her family. Besides selling vegetables, she also sells new and second hand-clothes ("mitumba clothes").  She needs a loan of KES20,000 to buy more vegetables. In the future she wants to be a wholesaler. Risper describes herself as an ambitious lady.

loans.use: To increase her stock of vegetables.

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana is a 56-year-old divorced mother of four children, some of whom are still in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in the town of Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town, but the majority of its inhabitants practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation, in addition to other business activities. 

Nana sells livestock. She buys live animals, such as goats and sheep, from nearby communities, and she sells them to butchers and food vendors in her community. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to sell livestock on larger scale.

loans.use: To buy livestock to sell

loans.name: Claver

texts.en:
Claver S. is 51 years old. He is married and has two children, ages 14 and 16. He lives in the Nyamagabe District of the Gikongoro Province of Rwanda where he has operated his business of grinding tools since 2006.  He employs two people from his community as helpers. His business is open each day from 6 AM to 6 PM.

Claver is requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders to buy a new and better quality grinder. He hopes this will allow him to serve more customers, which will help him to earn more profits. With the profits he hopes to earn, he plans to continue to reinvest into his business so that it will expand. Also, he plans to set aside money that will allow him to pay his children's school fees and, one day, to buy his family a house.

loans.use: To buy a new grinding machine

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 30-year-old divorced mother of one son who is in school. She lives with her child in a rented apartment in the town of Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town, but the majority of its inhabitants practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation along with other trading activities. 

Elizabeth prepares and sells rice-porridge in the mornings. She hawks (sells door-to-door) in her community. Elizabeth buys the goods from nearby communities. She has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Kamuli Group Of Lugazi

texts.en: N. Madinah is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a friendly and determined lady with a dairy business that she has owned for a long time. She sells milk, ghee (clarified butter), bread and cakes from her dairy shop. She buys her milk from farmers in the villages to supplement the milk that she gets from her cows at home. She buys the bread and cakes from factory moving vans; this provides a variety of goods for her to sell. Madinah is also a farmer. She grows maize, beans and bananas and raises animals, such as cows and chickens. She needs a loan to buy more milk to resell and to employ laborers to clear her farmland.

loans.use: To buy more milk, bread and cakes to sell

loans.name: Umulisa

texts.en:
I. Umulisa is 45 years old and is a widow with five children aged 9 through 22. Imaculee and her family live in Ngoma district in the Kibungo province of Rwanda which is a two-hour drive from Kigali. Immaculee has become an entrepreneur by necessity and so far she is succeeding.

I. has only two years of experience in her business of selling a variety of soft drinks, fruit and cakes. Her shop requires that she be at work every day from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. She employs one person (a helper) so that her business runs well and she can have a well-deserved break now and again.

I. would like to borrow from Vision Finance Company in order to improve her inventory and offer more products to her clients. Following this strategy, she believes, will allow her to earn more profit which will allow her to grow her business and begin to set aside money for herself and her family as well as pay for immediate expenses like food and schooling.

loans.use: To buy more milk, fruit and cakes to sell

loans.name: Wisdom

texts.en: Wisdom is 24 years old, and is single with no children. He lives alone in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Wisdom is a trader in motor spare parts. He buys the spare parts from nearby towns and sells them in a store by the roadside in his community. Wisdom has been in business for six years and wants a loan to procure all kinds of spare parts to increase his stock.

loans.use: To buy motor spare parts

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is 32 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works hard to support her husband in providing for their family. Monica is a trader in printed textile fabrics. She buys the textiles from nearby towns and sells in a shop by the roadside in her community. She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk so she can expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics in bulk

loans.name: United Friends Group

texts.en:
Melvin D. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Friends. He is 29 years old, married and has two children, aged five and ten. They are in kindergarten and 4th grade respectively. Melvin dropped out of school at 11th grade due to poverty. Melvin and his family live and work on New Port Street, a community in downtown Monrovia that is mixed with both poor and middle-class Liberians.

Melvin buys slippers from wholesalers and sells them retail on a table on New Port Street. He has been running this business for about four years. He started with a small amount saved from his salary as a security guard, and he hopes to improve the business and move to a bigger store in the future. Melvin talks to his customers in a good manner and sells his slippers at affordable prices in order to encourage his customers to continue buying from him.

He needs this loan to purchase more slippers to improve his business. Melvin dreams of giving his children a better education and setting them up in business.

loans.use: To purchase more slippers

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a food vendor. She prepares and sells a local dish called banku (cooked corn dough). Elizabeth prepares the food at home and sells by the roadside in the mornings. She buys goods from nearby communities. She has been in business for some time now and wants a loan to procure bags of maize, etc.

Elizabeth is a 40-year-old divorced mother of one daughter who is in an apprenticeship. She lives with her child in a rented apartment in the town of Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town; however, the majority of the inhabitants practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation alongside other trading activities.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Can Wange Pe Apora Christine Group

texts.en:
A. Christine is a 37-year-old married mother of four school-aged children. She also has one dependent for whom she cares.

For the past five years Christine has been running a salon. She is requesting a loan to purchase items for the salon, such as hair chemicals, gel, hair foods, combs, driers, etc. Since she is a professional hairdresser and a promising businesswoman she really wants to attract more and more customers into her salon. Her dream is to build a house in the future.

loans.use: To purchase salon items such as hair chemicals, gel, hair foods, combs, driers, etc.

loans.name: Grolia

texts.en:
Grolia M. is 31 years old, married with three children of her own, and also takes care of six dependents aged between 2 and 22. This large family of eleven, all live together in Ngoma district, Kibungo Province, where her pharmacy is located as well.

Grolia has a proven track record as an entrepreneur. She has ten years of experience in the business of selling animal medicines and veterinary services and employs one person from her community. She is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to grow her business by purchasing more supplies and equipment. This will allow her to serve more customers which will (hopefully) allow her to earn more profit.

With any additional profit she earns from this strategy, Grolia plans to reinvest in her business as well as save money and build a more secure future for her large family.

loans.use: To purchase more medical supplies and equipment

loans.name: Seth

texts.en: Seth is 45 years old, and is married with three children, all of whom are in school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Seth runs a transportation business. He owns a number of commercial vehicles and employs drivers to work for him. Seth has been in business for 15 years and is requesting a loan to repair some of his vehicles and keep them in good working condition.

loans.use: To repair his vehicles

loans.name: Rabi

texts.en:
Rabi is a food vendor. She prepares and sells porridge on a tabletop by the roadside in the mornings. She is 30 years old, married and has given birth to one girl who is in school. She lives with her daughter and husband in a rented apartment in the busy commercial town, Ejura, in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Rabi works to help her husband provide financially for the family. Rabi procures goods from nearby communities. She has been in business for over ten years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk. She is hoping to give her child the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en:
Immaculee M. is 51 years old, married with two children ages 19 and 21. Immaculee lives with her family in Ngoma district, Kibungo province of Rwanda which is 2 hours from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Immaculee has 13 years of experience in her business selling beverages and other grocery-type items such as Fanta, milk, snacks, and breads. Her shop is open every day from 6 AM to 9PM and employs two people who work as helpers to keep her business running well.

Immaculee is applying for this loan to help grow her business by purchasing additional inventory and supplies which she believes her current customers will want and which will also attract new customers to her store. If successful, this strategy will allow her to earn more profit, which will allow her to grow her business and save money for herself and her family.

loans.use: purchase milk, Fanta, bread and other inventory/supplies

loans.name: Felix

texts.en: Felix is 27 years old, single and has no children. He lives alone in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Felix is a carpenter by profession. He works in a workshop on the street in his community and has some apprentices he is training. Felix makes all kinds of furniture for his clients and for sale. He has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to buy wood, plywood, nails, and other working materials to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy wood, plywood, nails, and other working materials

loans.name: Vedaste

texts.en:
Vedaste K. is 48 years old, married with 9 children, aged between 3 and 25.  Vedaste and his large family live in Gicumbi district, the northern province of Rwanda where his small shop is located.

Vedaste has been in this business for two years and has been successful so far. His shop is open every day from 7AM to 5PM. He also employs two people from his community. 

Vedaste is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to purchase more inventory and supplies which he believes his customers will want to buy and which may attract new customers as well.  All of this, if successful, will help him to earn more profit and grow his business.
 
 Vedaste will use any extra profit he earns to feed his family better quality food and for paying the school fees of his many children.

loans.use: Purchasing more inventory and supplies and clothing for sale

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica, 28, trades all kinds of utensils. She hawks to sell and also treks to other communities to sell on their market days. Monica buys the goods from nearby towns. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure utensils in bulk to expand her business.
Monica is married and has given birth to two children, both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town; however, the majority of the inhabitants practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation alongside other trading activities.

loans.use: To buy utensils

loans.name: Nereah Adhiambo

texts.en: Nereah owns Nereah's Beauty Salon Point where she sells beauty products and chemicals to all types of people and also offers salon services. She has two employees and her main business challenge is power rationing. Demand for her salon services has increased and she needs a loan of 15,000 KES to buy more driers. Nereah is married with two children and describes herself as a stable businesswoman.

loans.use: To buy more driers for her salon

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a 49-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with her husband and their three children. Mariam has owned a bakery since 2007. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. She sells mankoucheh. Mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza. The most common toppings are za'atar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Mariam is known for her good and tasty mankoucheh. Her clients are her friends and neighbors.

Mariam requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials for her bakery. This is her second loan cycle and she has always repaid on time. She decided on this business because she wanted to supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans on opening a restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for her bakery

loans.name: Kelly's Vocational Secondary School, Hastings Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the Kelly’s Vocational Secondary School in Hastings, near Freetown. This school was founded in 1980 by Plan International and members of the Jui Community.  The school is staffed with twelve teachers and a total of 500 pupils. These staff are requesting a loan of 5,800,000 in total from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. 

Teachers and other monthly wage earners come to SMT/Shine on Sierra Leone to seek a loan in order to supplement their monthly salaries, which are usually too small to enable them buy or invest in anything productive. With this loan, some of them will invest in either their own business or their wives’ business, some will buy pieces of furniture, while others will invest in their children’s education. Some will use it to buy either a piece of land or house building materials.  

The leader of this group of teachers is Abdulai S. B..  Abdulai is a senior teacher at the school and the head of this group. He has been a teacher for sixteen years. Abdulai is forty-one years old, and was born in Masanga village about eight miles from Magburaka. Abdulai is married to a businesswoman and they have eight children, some of whom are in Senior Secondary Schools and others in Junior Secondary. Abdulai will use his loan to pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children.

loans.use: Pay school fees for his children and other personal needs

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is forty-six years old. She is married and has given birth to six children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town. However, the majority of the inhabitants practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation alongside other trading activities.

Mary trades in utensils. She sells at the local market and also treks to other communities to sell on their market days. Mary buys the goods from nearby towns. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy all kinds of utensils to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy utensils to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn P. lives in Brgy.1, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She is 54 years old and married with three children who are between 31 and 34 years old, and have their own families. In spite of her children making their own way in life, Evelyn continues to strive to earn a living, not only for herself and her husband, but also because she wants to help her grandchildren have more opportunities.

Years ago, Evelyn went into business to help her husband pay for the ever-increasing household expenses and to help with her children's school expenses. She started with a rice-retailing business, selling rice to people in her neighborhood and nearby villages, and this helped their family quite a lot. In 2004, with a pig-fattening business in mind, Evelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon and went into what has turned out to be a good backyard venture for her and her family. Now, their small piggery business earns an average net profit of $88 a month.

Her piggery business is doing quite well. In her previous loan she borrowed Php 17,000, which she used as additional capital for both her rice-retailing and her pig-fattening businesses. She was able to pay that loan off within its loan term without any delays. This time around she is borrowing another PHP 17,000, which she intends to use as working capital for her piggery.

Evelyn is shown in the accompanying picture, posing in front of her backyard pigpens.
 
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her piggery

loans.name: Fawe Grafton Primary School Group

texts.en:
These are some of the teachers of the FAWE (Forum for African Women Education) Grafton Primary School, located a short distance outside of Freetown. The school was established in 1992 and now serves nearly 300 pupils with a staff of only 9 teachers. These select teachers are seeking a loan of 4.1 million LE from SMT (a partner of Shine On Sierra Leone, Waterloo) and Kiva lenders.

Many teachers in Sierra Leone do not earn enough wages to support themselves and their families, so they conduct side businesses or invest in additional projects (often managed by friends or family members). These teachers are requesting loans for a variety of reasons, including buying stock for market stalls, paying school fees for their children, and doing construction or repairs on their homes.

Jeneba B. is the senior teacher at the school and the leader of the group. She is 36 years old and is married to a police officer. They have three children together who attend school. In addition to teaching her classes, for the past two years Jeneba has kept a small supply of goods such as cigarettes, pens, and bar soaps which she sells after school.

loans.use: Buy stock for small-scale business of selling goods

loans.name: Susan M.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of a primary school in Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 4,200,000 Sierra Leonean Leones to supplement their monthly salaries. With this loan, some of them can invest in their businesses, or pay school fees for their children. Some will buy a piece of land or house-building materials, while others will use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, like a bed, chairs, table or a television set. At the end of each month, the school’s bursar will deduct the total repayment amount owed SMT out of their salaries and repay SMT on their behalf.

Susan M. S. (right) is a teacher in charge at the school and the leader of this group. She is thirty-six, married to a teacher, and they have three children together. One of Susan’s children is attending Junior Secondary School III (JSS III), another is in Primary school VI and the last is not of school-going age. Susan has been a teacher for over fifteen years now. She will use this loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 36-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their five children. Mahmoud has owned a toy shop since 2005. In his toy shop he also sells candies. Mahmoud is unique in his work because he owns a big variety of toys, and children love coming to his shop. His clients are his friends and neighbors.

He requested a loan from the Kiva field partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase merchandise for his store, especially because the holiday season is close. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time.

When Mahmoud first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of cash. He decided to start his business because he wanted to have independent work, and he realized that there weren’t any gift shops in his neighborhood. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Yasser

texts.en:
Yasser is a 47-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Yasser has owned a beauty salon for almost two years now. He also does makeup, tattoos and hair removal. Yasser is good at his work because he knows how to treat his customers. His clients feel comfortable going to his salon because he offers a lot of services. His clients are his friends and neighbors.

He requested a loan from Al Majmoua, a Kiva field partner, in order to purchase more beauty products for his salon. This is the first time that Yasser has requested a loan.

When Yasser first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties because he already had faithful customers from his previous job. He decided to open his business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products for his salon.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is 47 years old and married with six children. Her husband is a government worker. To make a living, Caroline sells electrical parts in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a focused, hard worker. She hopes to be the sole distributor of electrical parts in her community in Lagos state. She hopes for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more electrical parts to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical parts to sell

loans.name: Talemwa Group Of Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Justine is a determined and hard-working lady and the leader of her group in Lugazi. She is 39 years old and divorced with 6 children from 15 to 30 years of age. She also takes care of her siblings.

Justine is a business lady who has been involved in the sale of agricultural produce for twelve years so far, and she is happy that she is able to make about $27 in profits a week. She has good customer care skills. Justine says that her biggest challenges are the scarcity of produce and the competition from other people in the same business. She is grateful for her loans because they enable her to buy quality goods.  

She has a dream of building rental houses that could bring in more income for future savings. At the moment, Justine needs a loan to help buy more produce for resale in order to have a steady supply of products for her customers.

loans.use: To buy more agricultural produce for resale.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 29-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Ahmad has owned a bakery since 2008. He makes mankoucheh, which looks like a folded pizza. The most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it any time of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Ahmad is known for his good and tasty mankoucheh. His clients are his friends and neighbors.

He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials for his bakery. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time. Ahmad decided on this business because he always wanted to open a bakery. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for his bakery.

loans.name: Zouheir

texts.en:
Zouheir is a 49-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Zouheir has been repairing cars since 1983. Zouheir is special in his work because of his experience. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase spare parts such as springs and shock absorbers for his work. This is his third loan cycle and he has always paid on time.

Zouheir started his car repair business, nor because he faced difficulties, but because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on enlarging his business.

loans.use: To purchase automobile spare parts.

loans.name: Isaac Okwaro

texts.en:
Isaac rears and sells chickens to hotels. In addition, he grows and sells sugarcane. He comes from an area rich in sugarcane plantations. In Kakamega (western Kenya), chicken is considered to be a delicacy, and Isaac is requesting a loan of KES20,000 to expand his business and become a wholesaler. His biggest business challenge is transportation costs.

Isaac is married with seven children ranging from 12 to 24 years of age. He is the sole breadwinner for the family.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for sale

loans.name: Darine

texts.en:
Darine is a 27-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Darine has been selling accessories. She sells necklaces, earrings, bracelets, make-up, women's tops and lots more. Her customers are her friends and neighbors. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new merchandise for her shop since the holiday season is arriving. This is the first time that Darine has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

When she first started her business, Darine didn’t face difficulties. Darine decided on doing her business because she wanted to supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans on expanding her work.

loans.use: To purchase new merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Rashidatu

texts.en: Rashidatu sells planks retail to earn a living. She is friendly and a hard-working woman. She is determined to excel in her business and family life. She is 27 years old, married with three children. Her husband sells motor vehicle spare parts to support the family. She hopes for the loan amount of 70,000 NGN to purchase more planks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 75-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their four children. Ahmad has been selling bags and other luggage since 2000. Ahmad is special in his work because he offers good quality products. His customers are his friends, neighbors and passers-by. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his work. Ahmad has been a micro-credit client for nine years now and has always repaid on time.

When Ahmad first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties especially since there is not a lot of competition and he has fair prices. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent business. In the future, he plans on enlarging his work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his business

loans.name: Alaa

texts.en: Alaa is 30 years old and lives in Beirut with his wife. He makes a living running a small coffee shop where he works hard to make his clients, who are also his friends and neighbors, feel comfortable. Alaa enjoys his work because it allows him to be independent and takes advantage of his experience working in other coffee shops. He has applied for this loan from Al Majmoua to buy a new espresso machine and other items he needs for his business. This is his third loan application, and he has paid his prior two loans on time. His goal for the future is to enlarge his shop.

loans.use: To buy a new espresso machine and other items for his coffee shop.

loans.name: Ghassan

texts.en: Ghassan is 48 years old and lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their five children. He has made a living repairing cars since 1983, and enjoys running his shop because of the independence it gives him. Also, his clients are friends and neighbors. Ghassan is applying for this loan to buy tools for his garage. This is his third loan, and he paid the first two back on time. His goal for the future is to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy tools for his garage.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia C. lives in Negros Occidental. She is 58 years old, married and has one child, who is 25 years old. Because of her strong determination to help her husband improve their living conditions, she saved their family from penury at a very critical point in it its past.

Many years ago, Delia and her family lived a comfortable life. In addition to the stable salary that she and her husband earned from working at the biggest sugar mill in the island, Delia also owned and managed a restaurant that catered to and was patronized by the employees in the sugar mill. Then, because of many factors, including a sugar crisis and other economic downturns, the sugar mill closed down and let the majority of its employees go. Delia lost her business as a result.

Fortunately, severance pay from the company allowed Delia to start a small general store, from which she earned her daily income. With her hard work and diligence, Delia was able to recover from their financial downturn and in 2002, joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to access additional capital. With help from this organization, her business continues to grow, and now earns a monthly profit which is a big help in defraying their household expenses.

Delia has taken out and repaid a dozen loans from NWTF-PD. She plans to use this new loan to keep her general store well stocked at all times and continue to earn a good income for her family.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory for her general store

loans.name: Risikatu

texts.en: Rasikatu is 36 years old, married and has two children. Her husband makes a living selling spare parts for motors. Rasikatu helps support her family, and put food on their table, by spending many hours each day selling wood to customers in Lagos state, Nigeria. She has applied for a loan for 70,000 NGN to buy more planks to sell, and extends her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more wooden planks to sell

loans.name: Wissam

texts.en: Wissam is  34 years old and lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon, where he owns and runs a grocery store. He sells canned food, candies, drinks and many other items, and enjoys running his own business. Wissam has lots of experience in this line of work, and his customers are almost all friends and neighbors. He has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua to buy more items to sell from his store. This is the third loan he has applied for; he paid the first two fully, and on time. In the future, he plans to expand his store.

loans.use: To buy merchandise to sell from his store.

loans.name: Can Wange Pe Acayo Christine Group

texts.en: A. Christine is the group representative. She is a fifty-year-old businesswoman, married with six children. Four of her six children are in schooling. She has a fish selling business and she has been operating this business for over ten years. She is requesting this loan to purchase fish for sale. She wants to add stock to her business. She is a promising, hard working busy woman whose dream is to obtain livestock (cows) for her family.

loans.use: To purchase fish for sale.

loans.name: Salim Mukabana

texts.en: Salim Mukabana M. owns Mukabana Traders general shop where he sells sugar, sanitary towels, cooking oil, stationery, flour and salt to a nearby school and to retail customers.  His challenge in business is lack of enough capital to restock his store.  He wants to buy more sugar, rice, flour, and stationery materials.  Salim describes himself as hardworking. He is a visionary man and has a wife and five children ranging from age four to fifteen years. His business is the only source of income for the family. He would like to open a big wholesale store five years from now.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, flour and stationery materials.

loans.name: Saied

texts.en:
Saied is a 52-year-old man who lives in Beirut, capital city of Lebanon, with his wife and their four children. Saied has owned an accessory shop where he sells toys, home products (like dishes, home accessories etc…) and faux bijoux. Saied is special in his work because he offers a wide range of products. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. Saied has been a microcredit client for five years now and has always paid on time. 

When Saied first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Soumaya

texts.en:
Soumaya is a 55-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, capital city of Lebanon, with her husband and their three children. Soumaya has owned a grocery store for three and a half years. She sells canned food, candies, etc. Soumaya requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. This is her second cycle loan and she has always paid on time. 

Soumaya is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she had to face some financial issues. Soumaya decided on doing her business because of her networking in her region. In the future, she plans on improving her work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Rachid

texts.en:
Rachid is a 49-year-old man who lives in Beirut, capital city of Lebanon, with his wife. Rachid has been working as a car repairman since 1990. Rachid is special in his work because of his experience. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. Rachid has been a microcredit client for five years now and has always paid on time. 
When Rachid first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing his business because of his experience and he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work.

loans.name: Azniv

texts.en:
Azniv is a 47-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Azniv has owned a clothing shop since 1980. Azniv is special in his work because he has competitive prices. His clients are his friends and neighbors. 

He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is his fourth cycle and he has always paid on time. When Azniv first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work and because of his experience is sales. In the future, he plans on expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita C. lives in the village of Brgy. Canmoros, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She is 59 years old, married and has three children who are 32 to 37 years old. Because of her determination, hard work and dedication to help her children finish their college education, she finally achieved this aspiration. Now she dreams to continue improving their quality of life, her most immediate objective being to buy one more motorcycle as a business asset and to repair their house in the future.

Once upon a time, Teresita was not sure if she and her husband would be able to provide well for their family. This was because she knew that her husband's income was just not enough to cover all the expenses of their family, which included the school expenses of their three children. This is why in January of 1991, Teresita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon so that she could borrow capital to start a business that could supplement her husband's earnings. She went through the necessary training seminar so that she could understand what was expected of her as an PD member. When she received her first loan, she started a general store adjacent to their family home. Because of its good location, it was able to earn a good income for her and her family.  At the next opportunity to start another business, Teresita went into rice retailing, sold dried fish and even charcoal to expand her product offerings and increase her income potential. She even bought a motorcycle as another source of income. Now she earns an average of 20,000 Philippine pesos per month, which is really a respectable income for a rural location.

For her previous loan, she borrowed Php 20,000, which she used as additional capital for her businesses. Having paid that, while maintaining her good credit standing, Teresita is now borrowing for her 17th cycle loan the same amount, Php 20,000, to be used as revolving capital for her business. Any income will used to buy the new motorcycle that she dreams to add to her ever-growing income sources.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 29-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Mohamad owns a bakery. He does mankoucheh. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza. The most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. 

Mohamad is special in his work because he is known for his good and tasty mankoucheh. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials for his bakery. This is the first time that Mohamad has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. Ahmad decided on doing his business because he always wanted to open a bakery. In the future, he plans on expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for his bakery

loans.name: Mamadou Moustapha

texts.fr: Mamadou Moustapha D. est célibataire, tailleur membre de l’U-IMCEC a la caisse de Baye Laye depuis plusieurs annees.Il a déjà rembourse six prets.Depuis 1989 il exerce cet activité mais ce n’est qu’en 2003 qu’il a acquit son propre atelier et travaille pour son propre compte. Il est ne dans une famille de tailleur et fréquentait  régulièrement l’atelier de son grand frère d’où il a choisi le métier par amour .Il sollicite un crédit de 250 000 frs dans le but de compléter  son épargne pour acquérir une nouvelle machine a coudre et ainsi pouvoir faire face a la demande croissante  de veille de fête de Tabaski et de fin d’année. Avec son emprunt il espère pouvoir augmenter ses revenus de 250 000 frs mensuellement. Son objectif est d’améliorer  considérablement  son  épargne et d’étendre son atelier.
texts.en:
Mamadou Moustapha D. is unmarried and a tailor. He has been a member of U-IMCEC at the branch office of Baye Laye for several years. He has already repaid six loans. He has been in this business of tailoring since 1989. But it was only since 2003 that he acquired his own workshop and has worked for himself. He was born into a family of tailors and used to go to his older brother’s shop regularly. Thus, he chose this trade for the love of it. He’s requesting a loan of 250,000 francs with the goal of rounding out his savings to acquire a new sewing machine and thus to be able to cope with the growing demand ahead of the Tabaski Festival and New Year’s Day. With this loan, he hopes to increase his monthly revenues by 250,000 francs. His goal is to improve his savings considerably and to expand his workshop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en: Fumilayo is 39 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a carpenter. All her children are schooling. She hopes to give her children a quality education. She sells spiritual items like candles, olive oil, and incense in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a hard working woman and she is determined to excel in her business and family life. The high season for her business is here and she hopes to meet the demands of her numerous customers. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more spiritual items to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase spiritual items to sell

loans.name: Zie

texts.en:
M. is married with five children and lives in Alabukam, a quarter in Bamenda, Cameroon. She will invest her loan in her pig business and in cultivation of crops. She plans to use the loan for increasing her number of pigs and fowls; fixing her pig and fowl stalls; and buying pig and fowl feed. This is M.'s ninth loan. She has been a member of GHAPE since 1999. This loan will help her pig and fowl business to succeed because she will be able to feed her pigs and fowls well, which will result in larger pigs and fowls that can be sold for a greater profit. She will also be able to purchase healthy piglets with access to more capital. She plans to use the manure from her pigs and fowl both for her personal crops as well as to sell in the community.  
 
With the profits from this loan, M. will open a workshop for her daughter. She will also pay her children’s school fees and those of the children of her late sister, and ensure that they are well prepared for school. The training in business management that she received from GHAPE will help her to invest this loan in the most efficient and productive manner. 
 
Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a very multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff, and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, fowls and feed and to cultivate crops for sale

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget sells soup ingredients at retail prices to make a living. She is 53 years old and married with four children. Her husband works with the government. She is a focused, hard worker. She hopes to be the sole distributor of soup ingredients in Lagos state, Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more soup ingredients to sell. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more soup ingredients to sell

loans.name: Iddrisu

texts.en: Iddrisu A. is married and has four children. He has been through commercial school.  Iddrisu is a poultry farmer and sells birds and eggs at Elmina fish pot, which he has been doing since 1984. His wife is a trader.  Iddrisu uses his income to pay school fees and utility bills.  Iddrisu will use the loan to buy more feed and drugs for his poultry. With the new profits from his expanded business, Iddrisu plans to save to invest.

loans.use: To buy feed and drugs for his poultry.

loans.name: Youth For Truth Group

texts.en:
Tarweh G. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Youth for Truth. He is 27 years old and married with a 7-year-old child in kindergarten.
Tarweh is a high school graduate and trying to enroll in the University of Liberia. 
He and his family live and work on the battle field in West Point, a community that is full of poor Liberians. The crime rate is very high there and it is close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia.
Tarweh’s business is tailoring. He buys fabric from wholesalers, sews nice designs and sells to residents of West Point. He has been running this business for about eight years. He learned tailoring in his youth and decided to take tailoring as his career.
Tarweh is hoping to become a bigger designer and have a large boutique in the future. Tarweh sews well, has new designs and talks to his customers in a good manner of approach in order to encourage them to continue buying from him.
He needs this loan to purchase more fabric to sew more clothes for the Christmas season.
Tarweh dreams of giving his children a better education and good medical attention when needed.

loans.use: To purchase more fabric to sew more clothes

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is married and does not yet have children. He lives in Alabukam, a neighborhood in Bamenda, Cameroon. Samuel and his entire family live in a 2-room house. Samuel had to overcome challenges in life such as ill health and little or no education provided by his parents. He farms in order to earn a living.

This will be Samuel's ninth loan from GHAPE. He has been a member since 1998. He has been quite successful in the past with his business due to its location and his reasonable prices. Also, with experience, he is now receiving good yields from his farm.

Part of the profits from this loan will be used to build a house, improve on his farming system, and reinvest in his farm.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profit and loss, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy seedlings, to clear farmland, and to till soil.

loans.name: Bolaji

texts.en: Bolaji is 43 years old and married with four (4) children. Her husband sells electrical materials and they live in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells bunches of plantain at retail prices to her customers. The demand for her plantain is high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. Plantain in Nigeria can be prepared by boiling, roasting and frying. It is a staple food in Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more bunches of plantain to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bunches of plantain to sell

loans.name: Ekuka

texts.en: Ekuka G. sells food supplies such as canned tomatoes, fresh ginger, locally made spices and so on at Elmina fish pot.  Ekuka has received a senior high education.  She is single and has four children. Ekuka has been selling food supplies since 1979. She is responsible for the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more food supplies for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to invest.

loans.use: To buy more food supplies for sale.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria sells crates of drinks at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is 35 years old and married with four (4) children. Her husband is a commercial driver and they live in Lagos state, Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Ana Milagros

texts.es:
La socia ANA MILAGROS, pertenece al banco comunal “AMAUTA”, es natural de la ciudad del Cusco.

La socia tiene 35 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene una hija de diez años que cursa el nivel primario, ella es madre y padre para su menor hija. Ella alterna sus actividades del hogar con el negocio de confección de ropa para niños y con la venta de disfraces para niños, la socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar su producción en la adquisición de más material (lana de alpaca) para la confección de chompas, chalinas, guantes, etc.      .
  
La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Ana Milagros belongs to the Amauta Communal Bank. She is from the city of Cusco. She is 35 and a single mother. She has a ten year old daughter who goes to primary school. She is both mother and father to her minor daughter. She alternates between her household activities, her business of making children’s clothes, and selling children’s costumes. She needs a loan to increase production by purchasing more material (alpaca wool) to make sweaters, scarves, and gloves, etc. She is grateful for the opportunity offered through this medium, and she promises to make her payments according to the established time line.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy material for making children's clothes

loans.name: Lizzette

texts.es:
La señora vive en casa de sus familiares en la c/ Gregoria Apaza  zona de Achachicala de la ciudad de La Paz es comerciante y trabaja con abarrotes (vende azucar, arroz, harina y otros) y refrescos.

El crédito que solicita es para comprar más productos y tratar de mejorar sus costos para obtener un mejor margen de ganancia.  

Es cliente de Impro desde el año 2008 y tiene un buen historial de pagos..
texts.en:
This lady lives in her family’s house, which is on the Gregoria Apaza block in the Achachicala region of the city of La Paz. She is a business woman, and she works with groceries (she sells sugar, rice, flour, and others) and soft drinks.
