The loan she is asking for is to buy more products and to try to improve her costs so that she can have a better margin of earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, flour, sugar, soft drinks and others for her retail sales

loans.name: John

texts.en: S. John is a 30-year-old businessman. He is married with three children. They are too young to go to school. He owns a grocery business situated in Lukaya central cell. He is a permanent resident of Kulubya cell and farms here.  He is using the loan to buy more stock for the grocery and to purchase fertilizer, seeds and pesticides to improve his agriculture methods for higher yields and better income.  His future hope is to succeed in life financially.

loans.use: To buy more groceries, fertilizer, seeds and pesticides.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah G. is single and has two children. She has received a junior high education.  Hannah has been selling smoked fish and koobi (sun-dried fish) at Elmina fish pot since 2000. Hannah uses her income to pay school fees, utility bills and other expenses of the house.  Hannah will use the loan to buy more fish and food supplies to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Hannah plans to save to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more fish and food supplies to sell.

loans.name: Asomdwe Mma Group

texts.en:
Janet started her trading business three years ago in the suburb where she lives. She is a petty trader and sells items like smoked fish, carrots, green pepper, onions, spices etc on top of a table in the community. She is now 56 years old and married with five children. All her children are also trading in business. Her husband is a farmer. She has been stuck without funds to make her business progress. She wants to use the loan to increase her stock of assorted fishes and vegetables to make more sales and income to support her business growth as we approach Christmas festivities. She will be grateful for the assistance. 

She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Asomdwe Mma’, which literally means peaceful family. She is the one sitting in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors, farmers etc. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more stock to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es:
La señora Cecilia vive en casa propia junto a su esposo y sus hijos en la c/ José Manuel Oponte zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí en la ciudad de La Paz; es comerciante y trabaja con la venta de carne de ovejas y cerdos, las cuales las vende en el mercado Strongest de la zona de Tembladerani.

El  crédito lo requiere para aumentar el capital de trabajo y poder comprar mas carne de cerdo, la cual es muy requerida por sus clientes.

Es cliente de Impro desde el año 2006 y paga bien, por lo tanto puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Cecilia lives with her husband and children in her own house on the José Manuel Oponte block of the Villa Nuevo Potosí in the city of La Paz. She is a business woman, and she works selling lamb and pork. She sells the meat in the Strongest Market in the Tembladerani region. She needs the loan to increase her working capital to be able to buy more pork. Pork is in much demand by her customers. She has been a client with Impro since 2006. She pays well, and that is why she can have access to a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a larger quantity of pork

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is 31 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a commercial driver. She sells foodstuffs to make her living in Lagos state, Nigeria. She hopes to be a foodstuff distributor in Lagos state in the future. She is determined to lift her business to the next level of progress. She hopes for the loan amount of 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
La señora Maria vive en Alquiler con su hijo en la c/ “D”  zona de Las Lomas de la ciudad de La Paz; es comerciante y trabaja con materiales reciclados que compra o  junta para luego comercializarlos por cantidad.

El crédito que ahora requiere será utilizado para aumentar su capital de trabajo y poder comprar más material para su venta posterior.

Es cliente de Impro desde el año 2006 y tiene un historial de pagos bueno y  por el carácter social del préstamo ella puede acceder a u nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Maria lives in a rented house with her son on the “D” block of the Las Lomas region in the city of La Paz. She is a business woman, and she works with recycled materials. She buys them or gets them together to be able to later sell them in bulk. The loan that she needs now is to increase her work capital and be able to buy more material for later resale. She has been a member of Impro since 2006. Because of her good payment history and her good character she is able to access a new loan

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a greater quantity of recyclable materials to later sell wholesale

loans.name: Dwen Daakye Group

texts.en:
Agyin is 42 years old. He is a married man with three children. All his children are in school. He is a baker who uses flour for his production. He bakes bread and sells it to his customers. He prepares and bakes sugar, butter and wheat breads. He supplies the breads by himself in the market center to his customers and people also take bulk delivery of bread from him. He has been in business for a year. 

His only problem now has to do with adequate funds to buy raw materials as we approach Christmas festivities. He requests a loan to remain in business and also to take care of his family. He believes it is not possible to realize his dream of expansion by himself. He would be grateful for assistance. Apart from the above business, he is also doing carpentry work and manufactures furniture like beds, tables, chairs, etc. 

He is the leader of a trust bank group called "Dwen Daakye," which means "think of the future." He is the one sitting in front in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and/or farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy baking materials like bags of flour, sugar, margarine, yeast and firewood

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina is married with five children. She lives in Alabukam, Cameroon. Christina and her entire family are living in a house with four rooms. Christina had to overcome some challenges in life, such as ill health and difficulties paying her children's school fees. She does farming in order to earn a living.

This will be Christina's fourth time to receive loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2005. She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to her location and her reasonable prices. Also with her experience, she is now having good yields from her farm.
 
Her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children, to buy necessities for the family and give them good medication whenever they are sick, and to plow back into her farm.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a nonprofit NGO (non-governmental organization) based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works toward the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying of seeds, clearing of the farm, tilling of the soil

loans.name: William

texts.en:
M. William is thirty-four years old; he is married with two sons who are not yet in school.

William has a retail grocery situated in Bajja trading centre and at the same time he is a professional teacher (civi servant) at King David High School in Lukaya Town. He is using the loan purposely to increase the stock in his grocery store for better profits and daily higher income generation for his business expansion.

William’s future plans are to make his business big for sustainability and to become a business-oriented person.

loans.use: To buy sweets (candies), soap, bread, sugar, etc. for his grocery store

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es:
El señor José Luís H. vive en casa de sus padres, en la zona  de Pasankeri, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor José Luís es policía de baja graduación de este municipio, ingresos con los que se mantiene. 
El crédito solicitado es para el acabado de un baño en la parte de la vivienda que le cedieron sus padres.
Esta es la cuarta vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
José Luís Huanta lives in his parents’ house in the Pasankeri region on the west side of the city of La Paz. José Luís is a low ranking policeman in this municipality. He uses this income to support himself. The loan he is asking for is to finish a bathroom in the part of the house his parents gave him. This is the fourth time that he has asked for a loan. The socioeconomic analysis that was completed favorably qualifies him, and he can access a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cost of material and labor to finish a bathroom in the house where he lives

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, a young entrepreneur, is married and has a boy one-and-a-half months old. Previously he used to sell clothes until he saw an opportunity for electronics from his friend. He has rented an electronics stand where he sells radios, torches (flashlights), batteries, belts, padlocks and watches. His business is located in a marketplace near a road and most of his clients are walk-ins and local residents.

John’s major challenge is lack of adequate storage for his valuable inventory and so he needs to rent space. John is borrowing KES 50,000 to buy more radios and lead products. He has also set funds aside for storage.

John is a friendly person and enjoys networking. His hopes are to see his only boy get the best education and to see himself as the only supplier of radios in the area in the next five years.

loans.use: To buy more electronic products to sell

loans.name: Mawuli Group

texts.en:
Rosina is 35 years old, divorced and the mother of a child in junior high school in the community where they live, a suburb of the eastern region of Ghana. Rosina, a rice and stew vendor in the community market, works very hard to support her child's basic needs. She started her operation about three years ago, but her food production is low because of inadequate funds to support her business. She is therefore requesting the loan to buy more meat, vegetables, and bags of rice to increase her business' efficiency, market share and profitability.

Rosina, the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Mawuli,’ which literary means There is God, is the one seated in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and farmers. In this group, members act as social collateral to access the loan and utilize peer pressure to ensure repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat and firewood etc.

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.es:
El señor Gregorio C. vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Pasankeri, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposa y sus tres hijos.
El señor Gregorio trabaja como chofer de transporte publico y su esposa es comerciante de ropa ambulante, ingresos con los que mantienen a su familia.
El crédito solicitado es para la construcción de dos habitaciones nuevas en su vivienda, porque sus hijos crecen y no cuentan con espacio suficiente.
Esta es la quinta vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Gregorio C. lives in his own house in the Pasankeri zone on the west side of La Paz. He lives with his wife and their three children. Gregorio is a public transport driver, and his wife is a roving clothing vendor. With these earnings, they support their family. This loan is for the construction of two new bedrooms in their house, as the children are growing and there is not enough space. This is their fifth loan, and it has been approved by the socioeconomic analysis.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of 2 new bedroom for their house

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en:
Folashade is 58 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a retired government worker.

Folashade sells drinks at retail prices to her customers in Lagos state, Nigeria and sells for long hours to ensure that there is food on her table for her immediate family members. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Rec Jui Lower Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of a primary school in Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Shine on Sierra Leone to seek a loan of 6,000,000 Sierra Leonean Leones for a number of reasons. As teachers’ salaries are usually small, SMT/Shine on Sierra Leone loans are very useful in helping them supplement their salaries.

This will be the first loan these teachers are accessing from SMT/Shine on Sierra Leone and Kiva. Like most teachers in Sierra Leone, the members of this group rarely have extra income with which they can buy or do anything great. But with a loan, they can now buy or do something big and then repay over a period of time.

Some of them will use their loan to begin or continue building a house, others to pay either for themselves to pursue further studies or pay for their children’s education. Some will use it to invest in businesses in order to supplement their monthly salaries and still others will use theirs to buy pieces of furniture and household goods.

The leader of this group of teachers is Samuel A. T.. He is a senior teacher at the school and has been in the teaching profession for thirty-one years now. Samuel is about forty-five years old and married with four children and one foster child. Two of his children are in Junior Secondary School II, the others are not of school going age, and his foster child is in primary school II.

Samuel will use this loan to buy house-building materials like rods and bags of cement, as well as furniture like chairs and a video set.

loans.use: To buy house-building materials, furniture and a video set

loans.name: Amudallat

texts.en: Amudallat, 55 years old and married with four children, sells planks at retail prices to her customers in Lagos state. A hard-working woman determined to excel in her business and family life, she hopes to be a plank distributor in the future.  Amudallat is requesting a loan amount of N70,000 to purchase planks to sell, and she says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase planks to sell

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses B. is a businessman who is 37 years of age. He is married and blessed with three children. Moses and his wife are teachers by profession, but they work hand-in-hand with one another to run their business. Moses has been in this business for over four years. He mostly deals in clothing for children age 6 to 10. His business is situated in Kiwumulo Acade, Elgine Street Masaka town. The name of his business 614 BABIES CORNER. 

His main aim for requesting a loan is to expand his business by buying more clothes. His future hope is to buy clothes for teenagers to boost his business.

loans.use: To expand his business by buying more clothes

loans.name: Dora

texts.es:
La señora Dora M. vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Pasankeri, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, con sus dos hijos.
La señora Dora es profesora de una unidad educativa en la ciudad de El Alto, ingresos con los que mantienen a su familia.
El crédito solicitado es para la refacción y el colocado de ducha de su baño, ya que no cuenta con ese servicio en su vivienda.
Esta es la sexta vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado la califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Dora M. lives in her own house in the Pasankeri zone on the west side of the city of La Paz, along with her two children. Dora is a teacher in an educational center in the city of El Alto, and her income from this work supports her family. The loan she is requesting will be used to carry out repairs and install a shower in her bathroom, since there is currently no shower in her home. This is the sixth time that she has requested a loan, and the socioeconomic analysis of her situation shows that she is favorably qualified to receive credit.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repairing her bathroom and installing a shower

loans.name: So Aba Pa Group

texts.en:
Married with five children, four in school and one a trader, Charity is 41 years old. She supports her husband in providing for the household through the sale of used clothing. Used clothing has a very big market in Ghana, as brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. She has been in this business for the past five years, making her sales through ‘hawking’, which is door-to-door sales. Charity wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory to meet customer demand, as in the Christmas season parents buy used clothing for their children. She believes this loan will help her to save for her children’s future and also to rent a store to trade.

The leader of a trust bank group called ‘So Aba Pa,’ which means ‘Bear good fruits,’ Charity is the one seated in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and farmers. The group members provide social collateral for one another to access the loan, and utilize peer pressure to ensure repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of used clothes

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 32 years old and is married with three children. Her husband sells yam tubers at wholesale prices.

Esther makes lovely hairstyles and she also sells hair materials like hair cream, shampoo and hair extensions to make a living in Lagos State, Nigeria.

Esther hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more hair materials to sell. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair materials to sell

loans.name: Lovina

texts.en:
N. Lovina S. is forty-eight years old; she is a widow and the mother of five children who have completed school.

Lovina runs a shop dealing with clothes and tailoring materials. She is requesting the loan with the interest of adding more tailoring materials (for example: more sewing threads, knitting wool, polyesters and cotton materials and others) in order to increase her sales.

Lovina’s future plan is to expand her business by buying more rolls of different materials to meet the demands of her customers.

loans.use: To add more tailoring materials to her shop

loans.name: Adonai Group

texts.en:
Comfort is 28 years old. She is married and has four children. She says that with the help of God all her children attend school and she is happy about that.

Comfort owns and operates a grocery shop in her neighborhood where she lives. She sells items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk, biscuits (cookies) and cosmetic products, etc. She works very hard in taking care of the family and sees her children as her future leaders who would one day change family hardships and living situations.

Comfort requests the loan support to buy stock in bulk to increase her inventory. With the loan, she wants to purchase more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of biscuits, etc. She hopes to improve her savings to support her children in school. She would be more than happy for your support.

Comfort is the leader of a trust bank group called “Adonai”. She is the one seated in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and farmers, etc.

loans.use: To buy stock in bulk to increase her inventory

loans.name: Enitan

texts.en:
Enitan is 23 years old and single without children. She sells for long hours to ensure that there is food on her table to feed her aged parents. She is a hardworking girl and she is determined to excel in her business.

Enitan hopes to be a distributor of drinks in Lagos State, Nigeria. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys, as she is popularly called by her numerous customers, is a 52-year-old local restaurant operator. She is married and blessed with four children of whom two are in school while two are traders.

Gladys prepares and serves local food like “banku”. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. She says prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditures. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

Before starting her business she was teaching kindergarten. She taught for several years but quit when she felt she was being cheated by the school authority. Gladys would be grateful for your assistance and has no regrets about her current food business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her restaurant

loans.name: Barbra

texts.en:
N. Barbra is a business lady aged thirty-two years. She is a single mother with three children.

Barbra owns a grocery shop in Kimaanya, Masaka municipality, and has been operating this business for over three years. She is using the loan to increase her business stock by buying more sugar, eggs, cooking oil, sweets (candies), bags of maize flour (for posho, also know as ugali - a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), rice and much more.

Barbra’s future dream is to expand her shop, especially by stocking it with the essentials for domestic use which will help her increase her number of customers.

loans.use: To increase her business stock

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is 32 years old. She is widowed and the mother of two who are both in school. Doris lost her husband through a prolonged sickness although she fought with all her money to give him life. Right now, all family responsibilities rest on her shoulders.

Doris prepares and serves her customers pastries like meat pie and doughnuts. She prepares them in bulk and sells through hawking (selling on foot) in the community market and its surroundings. She takes delivery of stock like flour, sugar, vegetable oil, etc., from Kade market.

Doris requests the loan assistance to buy stock to remain in business. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy flour, margarine, sugar, cooking oil etc.

loans.name: Anastasia

texts.en: Anastasia A. is married and has two children. She has received a senior high school education.  Anastasia sells plastic containers, bowls and so on at Elmina fish pot, which she has been doing since 2008. Her husband is a fisherman.  Anastasia uses her income to help her husband pay school fees and utility bills.  She will use the loan to purchase more plastic containers and bowls for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Anastasia plans to save to further her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase plastic containers and bowls to sell

loans.name: Biba

texts.fr:
Madame Biba  S. est âgée de 39 ans, mariée et mère  de 6  enfants.  Elle  vit avec son mari et ses enfants dans une famille traditionnelle avec plusieurs ménages au 1er quartier de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant vite abandonné l’école en classe de 6ème année (système éducatif Malien), elle  commença très tôt les activités génératrices de revenus en optant pour l’apprentissage du métier de teinturière,  auprès d’une de ses  belles sœurs, pendant 15 ans.  Aujourd’hui  elle jouit d’une grande expérience et notoriété. Elle maîtrise parfaitement les rouages de ce secteur d’activité. Sa réputation dépasse le cadre de Ségou.
Pour faire de la teinture, elle dilue différents produits de teintures modernes et traditionnels dans de l’eau chaude ensuite elle trempe les tissus blancs  dans cette eau pour leur donner la couleur voulue.  Les tissus teintés sont étalés sur une corde pour séchage. Ensuite elle les amène chez le couturier. Les habits une fois cousus sont  blanchis et soigneusement emballés.
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est à son 1er prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 3 pièces de bazins. Elle s’approvisionne sur place et à Bamako auprès des grossistes. Madame Biba  S.  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permet d’aider son mari et de participer aux événements sociaux (baptême, mariage etc.…). 
Son ambition est d’ouvrir une boutique de prêt-à-porter.
texts.en:
Ms. Biba S. is 39 years old, married, and the mother of 6 children. She lives with her husband and children in a traditional family with several households in the first district of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Soon after dropping out of school in 6th class (education system of Mali), she very soon started earning revenues by opting for an apprenticeship dyeing cloth. She learned this trade from one of her sisters-in-law 15 years ago. Today, she enjoys a lot of experience and distinction. She has an excellent command of the ins and outs of this business sector. Her reputation extends beyond Ségou. To dye cloth, she dilutes different modern and traditional dye products in hot water. Then she soaks white fabrics in this water to give them the desired color. The dyed fabrics are spread out on a rope to dry. Next, she takes them to a tailor. Once the clothing is sewn, it’s washed and carefully wrapped. With plans to increase her business capital, to realize bigger profits, she turned toward Soro Yiriwaso. She is on her first individual loan, which she intends to use to buy 3 bolts of damask cloth. She supplies herself locally and in Bamako from wholesalers. And she sells to customers composed of women and men, cash or credit accepted. With this loan, she anticipates earning a monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA. This will allow her to help her husband and to assist with societal events (baptisms, marriages, etc.) Her ambition is to open a ready-to-wear clothing store.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bolts of "rich" damask

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is 56 years old. She is widowed and the mother of four children. Two of her children are in school while the other two are traders. Her husband died after a prolonged sickness.

Janet is a supplier of local palm oil and also sells tubers of yam. Palm oil is produced from palm fruits. The palm oil is processed through various stages to obtain the palm oil which is used to prepare many local dishes like for frying fish, or for making pastries, or for making local soaps. She produces and supplies to food vendors to prepare their meals. However, her production is limited as a result of low working capital. Janet cannot afford a machine for the processing.

She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of palm fruits, tubers of yam, and an electric milling machine to reduce the drudgery of using manual effort. She will be able to produce palm oil in larger quantities. Janet believes the loan will enable her to save more toward her children's education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of palm oil and tubers of yam.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet N. K. is forty-five years old and married with five children who are all in school. She works together with her husband. She is working as a government servant in the education sector, but as a side business she runs a salon and a cosmetic shop. She has been in this business for over three years.

Harriet is requesting the loan with the aim of stocking more cosmetic products, like the different types of powder; that is, Johnson's sandalwood, Romance and others. She also wants to add more body sprays, creams, lotions, jellies, hair sprays, chemicals, etc. Her future dream is to expand her business. After buying most of the commodities to re-sell, she would like to become a wholesaler.

loans.use: To stock more cosmetic products.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 2 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso,  troisième région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur sixième  prêt de groupe. Les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente de fritures, d’atiecké, d’huile alimentaires, de savons traditionnels et  de la restauration, de la teinture etc.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter près d’une dizaine de complets de bazins teintés, 2 paniers et 1/2 de poissons fumés, 3 balles de friperie et 5 colorants différents  et 15kg de soude caustique. Elles s’approvisionnent aux grands marchés de la ville de Sikasso et à Bamako. Elles vendent dans les marchés de Sikasso ville, à domicile et de façon ambulante, au comptant et  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles ambitionnent demander des prêts plus importants pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles.
texts.en:
The members of the group Benkadi are married women averaging 32 years of age and 2 children each living mainly in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to meet the needs of their customers and are now on their sixth group loan. The past loans have been repaid. The women of the group sell atiecké fritters, cooking oil, and traditional soaps, and they work at food catering, dyeing cloth, etc. With their new loan, they intend to buy nearly a dozen dyed damask outfits, 2½ baskets of smoked fish, 3 bales of second-hand clothing, 5 different coloring agents, and 15 kg of caustic soda. Supplies are gotten at the big markets of Sikasso City and in Bamako. Sales are made in cash and often on credit to customers composed of men and women at the marketplaces of Sikasso City, in homes, and door-to-door. The group members each anticipate earning an average monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be put into savings and used for family needs. The other portion will be invested in the businesses. Their ambition is to ask for bigger loans to satisfy their customers further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Samuel E.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of a primary school in Sierra Leone. They have come to seek a loan of 10,500,000.00 SLL from SMT/Shine on Sierra  Leone (one of Kiva's field partners) in order to meet some of their immediate financial needs. As teachers’ salaries are usually small, SMT/Shine on Sierra Leone loans are very useful in helping them supplement their salaries. 

This will be the first loan these teachers are accessing from SMT/Shine on Sierra Leone/Kiva. This loan will certainly be of immense help to them. Since salaries are usually small in Sierra Leone (especially for people in the teaching profession) they could not use such salaries to buy or do anything great. With a loan, however, they can now buy or do something big and then repay over a period of time. Some of them will use it to begin or continue building a house; others to pay either for themselves to pursue further studies or to pay for their children’s education. Some will use it to invest in businesses in order to complement their monthly salaries, and still others will use theirs to buy pieces of furniture and household goods.

The leader of this group of teachers is Samuel E. W.. He is a teacher at the school and head of this group of teachers. He has been in the teaching profession for forty years now. Samuel is sixty-one years old and married to a businesswoman. They have four children. Three of his children attend Junior Secondary Schools (JSS) and the other is in Senior Secondary School (SSS). Samuel will use this loan to pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children.

loans.use: Pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian G. sells palm oil, frytol oil (vegetable cooking oil) and other kinds of oil for cooking, and also for the making of local soaps, at Elmina fish pot.  Vivian has received a senior high school education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a fisherman. Vivian has been selling palm oil, frytoyl, and so on since 1999. She helps her husband in the payment of utility bills and school fees. Her loan will be used to buy palm oil, frytol and other kinds of oil to re-sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and reinvest.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy palm oil, frytol and other kinds of oil to re-sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 46 years old, is widowed, and is the mother of eight children. Currently four of her children are in school while the others are trading.

Mary works hard as a single mother in taking care of her household. She prepares and serves “Bankye Kakuro” which is a local food prepared from milled cassava and is prepared through various stages. She sells it through hawking (going door-to-door) and it has a higher demand because of the good taste.

Mary requests the loan to help buy more bags of cassava to remain in business as demand has become high. With the business proceeds she dreams of supporting her children in school. She would be glad of your assistance.

loans.use: To buy a bulk supply of cassava, cooking oil, onions, etc.

loans.name: Luisa Amanda

texts.es: Luisa Amanda  tiene  47 años de edad, su actividad económica es brindar el servicio de taxi, hace mas de 11 años que se dedica a este negocio por lo que ella empezó con fondos propios, y así poco a poco fue luchando para tener su propio medio de vida, por lo que se dedicaba a vender comida por las noches en las afueras de su vivienda y así fue realizando sus propios esfuerzos. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la reparación de vehículo, pintura con espray que consiste en tapizado, cambio de llantas entre otras cosas. Su deseo es tener otro taxi para mejorar cada día las condiciones de vida
texts.en:
Luisa Amanda is 47-years-old and she works as a taxi driver. She has worked in this business for the past 11 years and she began it with her own money. Bit by bit she has worked hard for her livelihood which is why she also sells food at night outside her home through her own efforts. The requested loan is for working capital that will be used for vehicle repair such as spray painting, fixing the upholstry, and changing the tires, among other things. She desires to have another taxi to improve her daily living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: vehicle repair

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a 49-year-old local restaurant operator. She is divorced and is blessed with one child who has currently traveled abroad.

In her restaurant, Gladys prepares and serves local foods like "fufu" and "banku." Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain, and taken with all kinds of soup; banku is prepared from milled maize grains and is taken with hot pepper or soup. Gladys has been in business for the past twenty years now. She also sells foodstuffs like yam, maize and palm nuts to generate additional income to support herself and her family.

Gladys says the prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditures. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials, like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables, firewood, and other foodstuffs.

Gladys dreams of buying a brand new deep-freezer to enable her to freeze her leftover meats and fish, etc. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials for her restaurant

loans.name: Akoma Adweo Group

texts.en:
Theresa is married and has three kids and lives with her family in a small farming community in the eastern region of Ghana. She is 28 years old.

Theresa sells lingerie products like underwear, panties, brassieres, skirts, etc., and has been in business for three years now. She also trades in earrings and sells through hawking (selling on foot) in and around the community market.

Theresa is constrained by funds to run the business. She needs the loan to inject more working capital into the business to scale up her business progress as we approach Christmas festivities. She believes the loan will enable her to purchase good quality and a large quantity to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for that assistance.

Theresa is the leader of a trust bank group called “Akoma Adweo” which literally means a “sober heart”. She is the one seated in the middle in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and farmers respectively. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and provide peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase items like lingerie, underwear, material, etc.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya de l’association Benkadi sont  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 2 enfants et  vivant  dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative de la république  du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur huitième  prêt de groupe.  Tous les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente de fritures,du charbon de bois, du bois de chauffe , d’huiles alimentaires, de savons traditionnels, des condiments alimentaires, de la restauration etc.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter,  2sacs de 100kg de pommes de terre, 20 litres d’huile alimentaires,  2sacs de charbon de bois, 200kg de riz en plus de 5 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 7 bidons de 20 litres d’huile et 400 morceaux de savons traditionnels. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent dans les différents marchés de Sikasso ville et à domicile, au comptant et  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of group Danaya of Benkadi association are married women who average 35 years of age, 2 children and live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the neighborhoods of Sikasso town, 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institutionn inorder to meet the needs of their customers and they are on their eighth group loan. All past loans have been repaid correctly. They trade in frying, charcoal, firewood, food oils, traditional soaps, food ingredients, catering etc. With their new loan, they intend to buy 2bags of 100 kg of potatoes, 20 litres of food oils, 2 bags of charcoal, 200 kg of rice in addition to 5 packages of food ingredients, 7 gallons of 20 litres of cooking oil and 400 pieces of traditional soaps. They get their supplies in the big markets of Sikasso city and in the neighboring villages. They sell on the different market days of Sikasso town and from home for cash and sometimes on credit to a clientele made up of men and women. They hope to make an average monthly profit of 35 000FCFA each, of which a part will be used for saving and the needs of the family and the other part will be invested in the business.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Modou

texts.fr:
M. Modou B. est une tailleur experiencé à Baye Laye, une quartier de Guediwawe, une banlieue de Dakar.  Le tailleur est un métier qu'il a aimé à bas age, même s'il y a été former pour être commerçant, il a choisi son métier.  Il est active dans le métier depuis 1990.  

M. B. voudrais compléter le construction de la plafond de sa maison laquelle il a acheté en 2007.  La maison a 150 m2, avec quatre chambres, une cuisine et la toilette.  Il va habiter à la maison avec sa femme et ses deux enfants.  Cette pret est le deuxieme pour M. B..

Merci pour votre soutien d'UIMCEC!  Rejoignez-vous notre équipe Team Taff Taff 
www.kiva.org/team/tafftaff
texts.en:
M. Modou Bodine is an experienced tailor in Baye Laye, a neighborhood of Guediwawe, a suburb of Dakar. The work of a tailor is what he liked at a young age even though he had been trained to be a trader, he prefered his work. He is active in the work since 1990. Mr B. would like to complete the roof of his house which he bought in 2007. The house is 150 m2 with four rooms, a kitchen and toilet. He is going to live in the house with his wife and two children. This is the second loan for Mr. B.. UIMCEC thanks you for your support! . Join our team, Team Taff Taff at www.kiva.org/team/tafftaff

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Roof construction

loans.name: Huseyn

texts.en:
Huseyn M. is 47 years old. He is married with two children. Since he was very young, he has been in the business of raising and selling cattle, which is why he has a lot of experience. It is necessary to point out that he has been able to succeed thanks to the support provided by his parents and wife. This support has been in the form of borrowing and help, which he has used to purchase and raise young cattle in their locality. 

Today, Huseyn applied for a loan which will allow him to purchase young cattle to raise and sell. It is his biggest dream to improve the conditions of his business in order to then improve the conditions of his family.

loans.use: Purchase three cattle and fodder

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya de l’association Sindiya sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant  une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans, 3 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire. Tous  les deux  prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente du bois de chauffe, des savons traditionnels,  des condiments alimentaires etc.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, un chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 185 morceaux de savons traditionnels et 4paquets condiments alimentaires. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent  dans les marchés de Sikasso ville, à domicile et de façon ambulante, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members in the Danaya group of the Sindiya association are made up mainly of married women who are on average 30 years old, with 3 children and live in monogamous families. They live in Hamdallaye, a suburb of the city of Sikasso, the third administrative region im Mali. They work with the Soroyiriwaso microfinance company to meet their customers needs and they are making their third group loan. Their two previous loans have been duly repaid. They sell firewood, traditional soaps, basic food condiments, etc. With their new loan, they plan to buy, a truckload of firewood, 185 pieces of traditional soap and four crates food condiments. They buy their supplies at the main market in the city of Sikasso and in the surrounding villages. They resell their products in the markets of Sikasso, door to door and by hawking, for cash and often times for credit to a clientele made up of both men and women. They each expect to earn a monthly income of 23,000 CFA. Part of the profit will be used for savings and the needs of the family. Part will be invested in their business.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase supplies of varions products for resale

loans.name: Rajab

texts.en:
Rajab M. is a sheep breeder in the city of Saatli in Azerbaijan. Together with his wife, he has been raising sheep for more than 15 years. This produces the income which allows him to feed his three children and his wife. As well as caring for his sheep, he also cultivates agricultural crops, such as wheat, which helps with the family's diet and provides additional income.

Rajab has asked for this loan to buy lambs in order to obtain a better profit. His greatest wish is to be able to improve his farm by constructing enclosures and establishing better grazing for his sheep.

loans.use: Purchase 15 sheep

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
Martha Lorena tiene 46 años de edad, su actividad económica es el destace de cerdo. Hace más de 8 que se dedica a este negocio, el cual dio inicio vendiendo poco a poco y fue a partir de ese momento que fue reinvirtiendo en su negocio para hacerlo más grande, y poder vivir de ese negocio, ya que los trabajos están escasos en nuestro país. El crédito será invertido  en su negocio principalmente. A pesar de no tener una educación completa. Por lo que el deseo de Martha es  seguir con este empeño de salir adelante
Con su negocio.
texts.en:
Martha Lorena is 46-years-old and she works as a pork butcher. She has been in this line of work for more than eight years and she began her business by selling bit by bit. At this moment she is reinvesting in her business to make it larger so she will be able to live solely on this income, as jobs are scarce in her country. The loan will mainly be used to invest in her business. Despite not having completed her education, Martha desires to continue this effort to succeed with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital for pork butchering

loans.name: Akoma Group

texts.en:
Ama is 35 years old, married and the mother of four children. Three are currently in school and her last-born is still breastfeeding. She is a food vendor and serves food like waakye. Waakye is prepared from local rice grains and mixed with beans. Many Ghanaians enjoy it as it has local taste and standard. She says demand for food is on the higher side but she does not have adequate funds for expansion. She has been in food production for two years now, which helps in taking care of the family. She wants to use the loan to buy meat, rice and vegetables to increase her efficiency to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to support her children's educational needs. She would be grateful for the assistance. 

She is the leader of a trust bank group called "Akoma," which means heart. She is the one sitting in the middle in the group photograph. The members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, beans, meat, firewood, etc.

loans.name: Fatou Binetou

texts.fr: Fatou  Binetou  D. est une jeune dame de 33 ans très ambitieuse  qui habite la localité de Baye Laye a Guediawaye.Elle  est sociétaire de l’U-IMCEC  depuis 2004 et a déjà bénéficie  de 3 prets.Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle a une expérience de neuf ans dans son activité de commerce. Au début  elle achetait  chez les grossistes pour aller les revendre en placement jusqu'à ce qu’elle ait ouvert une cantine au marche. C’est depuis qu’elle était élève qu’elle a eu l’idée  d’essayer de travailler pour essayer de gagner quelque chose qui lui permette de financer ses etudes.ELLE  sollicite ce prêt de 500 000 frs pour  acheter des tissus et habits pour enfants en vue de renforcer Ses activités  commerciales.
texts.en:
Fatou Binetou D. is a very ambitious 33 year old young lady who lives in the town of Baye Laye in Guediawaye. She is a member of UIMCEC since 2004 and has already benefitted from 3 loans. She is married and the mother of a child. She has nine years experience in her trading business. At first, she used to buy from wholesalers to go retail at locations until she opened a cafteria in the market. Since becoming a student that she had the idea to try out working to earn something which will allow her to finance her studies. She is requesting this loan of 500 000 frs to buy children's fabrics and clothes in view of strengthening her business activities.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen her working capital

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Kotognogontala sont  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans, 4 enfants et  vivant  dans des familles monogames à Hamdallaye un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt de groupe. Tous les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles font la vente du bois de chauffe, des tissus, des savons traditionnels, des condiments alimentaires, des fruits et légumes, des tubercules  etc. 
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, un chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 185 morceaux de savons traditionnels et une vingtaine de complets en tissus pour hommes et femmes. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso, dans les villages avoisinants et au Burkina faso.
Elles vendent dans les différents marchés de Sikasso ville, à domicile et de façon ambulante, au comptant et  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Kotognogontala are married women averaging 30 years of age and 4 children each living in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, a district in the city of Sikasso (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women of the group are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to meet the needs of their customers and are now on their third group loan.  All the past loans have been repaid.  The women sell firewood, cloth, traditional soaps, condiments, fruit and vegetables, tubers, etc.  With their new loan, they intend to buy a cart-load of firewood, 185 bars of traditional soap, about 20 outfits made of fabrics for men and women.  Supplies are gotten at the big market of Sikasso City, in neighboring villages, and in Burkina Faso.  Sales are made in cash and often on credit to customers composed of men and women at the different markets of Sikasso City, in homes, and by going door-to-door.  The group members each hope to earn an average monthly profit of 27,000 francs CFA.  A portion of the profits will be put into savings and used for family needs.  And the other portion will be invested in businesses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Qoshqar

texts.en:
Qoshqar M. is a 26-year-old cattle breeder who has earned a living from raising cattle since he was teenager. He's not married yet but he is responsible for his aged parents.

It should be said that the low incomes available to people in this rural area aren't enough to maintain a family and for this reason, Qoshqar works enormously hard to provide a better standard of living for his current and future family.

Qoshqar urgently needs to buy animals such as cows and calves. He's applied for a loan of 1,606 AZN. Be an important part of the growth of Qoshqar’s business as he needs to save money to get married next year.

loans.use: To purchase two calves and a cow

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa N. is single and has six dependents. She has received junior high education.

Adjoa sells fresh fish and processed fish at Elmina near Mpoble, which she has been doing since 1999. She uses her income in payment of school fees and utility bills.

Adjoa will use the loan to buy more fresh fish for sale and also to process some of the fish by way of smoking them for the market. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish for sale and for smoking

loans.name: Help The Poor Group

texts.en:
Bawa G. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called “Help The Poor”. She is 42 years old and married with five children aged between 4 and 20 years old with educational levels of kindergarten through 12th grade.

Bawa is a 9th grade drop-out due to poverty. She and her family live in the Plumkor community, a residential area that is very crowded with people that migrated from rural Liberia during the civil crisis; it is south of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia.

Bawa’s business is foodstuffs. She buys foodstuffs wholesale like pepper, seasoning, garden eggs (eggplant), etc., and sells retail on a table to residents of her community. She has been running this business for nineteen years and started with LRD 2,000 (approx. $30). She organizes her goods and sells at an ideal location, satisfying her customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. She is hoping to improve to a shop.

Bawa needs this loan to purchase more pepper, salt and seasoning to improve her business. She dreams of building a house for her family and changing their standard of living in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more pepper, salt and seasoning to improve her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase two cows, two calves and fodder

loans.name: Sodnompil

texts.en:
Sodnompil B. is 22 years old and lives with his parents in the Uvurhangai province of central Mongolia. He and his parents live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. B. operates his own taxi service. He began working for another taxi service in 2005 as a shift driver and since then he has been able to purchase his own microbus and begin his own business. Eventually, he would like to trade-in his microbus for a larger bus so that he can take on more passengers and bring in more money. B. is a young man who is not afraid of hard work and long hours in order to improve both his and his parents’ lives. He is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase repair parts and upgrade his microbus for winter. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase repair parts and upgrade his microbus for winter

loans.name: Jantsandorj

texts.en:
Jantsandorj B. is a 45-year-old man who lives with his mother in the Uvurkhangai Province of Central Mongolia. He and his mother live together in a "ger," a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

B. operates a grocery and retail dairy business. He started his business in 2000 with 50,000 tugrugs of working capital. Since then, he has bought his own shipping container from which he operates his business and his working capital has grown to exceed 1,000,000 tugrugs. He would like to expand his business and be able to save money so that he can improve both his quality of life and his mother’s. 

B. is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (approx. $705 USD) loan to purchase a variety of dairy products for the upcoming winter months.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here

loans.use: To purchase a variety of dairy products for the upcoming winter months

loans.name: Maria Mercedes

texts.es: La señora Maria, ella tiene 28 años de edad, es madre soltera con tres hijos menores de edad, que ya están uno de ellos cursa el preescolar y el otro tiene 3 años de edad. La señora Maria tiene un negocio de compra y venta de ropa, tanto nueva como usada, los cuales vende de manera ambulante, principalmente por encargo a personas conocidas. Cabe señalar que la señora trabaja en un salón de belleza llamado salón de Belleza Luz Marina, lugar en el que utiliza para ofertar sus productos a sus compañeras de trabajo y a las personas que asisten a ese lugar. Este negocio empezó hace 5 años con muy poco capital  de trabajo, como una búsqueda de fuente de ingresos alternativos ya que acababa de tener a su primer hijo y necesitaba brindarle una buena manutención. Ella empezó vendiendo cosméticos, después fue que empezó a invertir en ropa y en adornos, además que también vende joyas, pero están son solamente por encargos.  El crédito será invertido en la compra de vestuario, ya que se acerca la época navideña y la señora desea invertir y comprar ahora que están un poco bajos los precios. Su meta es llegar a tener un una tienda de artículos variados que pueda estar ubicada en el mercado, que brinde las facilidades económicas a ella y a sus dos hijos.
texts.en:
Señora Maria is 28 years old and is a single mother of two minor children; one of them is in preschool, and another is 3 years old. Maria has a business buying and selling clothing, new as well as used, which she sells in the streets, principally on order to people that she knows. It should be noted that she works in a beauty salon called the Belleza Luz Marina salon, where she offers her products to her co-workers and customers of the salon. This business began 5 years ago with very little working capital. She was searching for a source of alternative income, since she had just had her first child and wanted to provide for him well. She started out selling cosmetics, after that she started to invest in clothing and accessories; in addition she also sells jewelry, but only on order. This loan will be invested in the purchase of more clothing, since it is now close to the Christmas season and Maria wants to invest and buy now when the prices are a little lower. Her goal is to eventually have a store located in the market that sells a variety of items; this would make it easier for her to provide economic support for herself and her two children.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Baljinnyam

texts.en:
Baljinnyam D. is 45 years old. He lives with his wife and three daughters in the Khovd Providence of Western Mongolia. The family lives in a "ger," a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His youngest daughter, age 13, attends a local secondary school and his middle daughter, age 20, attends a local university. His oldest daughter is currently looking for a job in their town. His wife is a tailor in a sewing company.

D. works as a taxi driver. He started his business in 2006 and, since then, has saved 3,000,000 tugrugs as a safety net for his family. He has seen a decrease in his business in the last year and is planning to trade his car for a large truck with several tons of hauling capacity so that he can transport materials instead of people. D. is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (approx. $1410 USD) loan to purchase a truck with at least 10 tons of hauling capacity.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here

loans.use: To purchase a truck with at least 10 tons of hauling capacity

loans.name: Baast

texts.en:
Baast T. is a 50-year-old widow who lives with her three children and one grandchild in the Khovd Province of Western Mongolia. The family lives together in a "ger," a yurt or traditional nomadic Mongolian tent. Her oldest daughter, 26, works as a bank teller. Her younger children, ages 17 and 14, attend a local secondary school, and her grandson, age 3, attends a local kindergarten. 

T. operates a clothing business in a shipping container in the local market. She started her business in 1999 in a stand inside the market, but she was able to buy her own container and now has more space for her products. Eventually, she plans to purchase another container so that she can have two locations from which to sell her clothing and hopefully improve her profits. Because of her hard work and good business sense, T. has been able to improve her family’s quality of life and buy a car. She hopes that she can help her oldest daughter and grandson move into a home of their own. She is requesting a 2,300,000 tugrug (approx. $1620 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of winter clothes for her retail business.		

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of winter clothes for her retail business

loans.name: Badarbirvaa

texts.en:
Badarbirvaa B. is 44 years old. She lives with her parents and her seventeen year old son in the Uvurhangai Province of Central Mongolia. The family lives together in a "ger," a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

B. supports the family by operating a sewing business.  She wants to eventually turn her small business into a factory with several employees. B. purchases materials for her business 1-2 times per month, depending on her customer’s wants and needs. She is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (approx. $2475 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of wholesale materials in order to attract new customers to her business.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of wholesale materials in order to attract new customers to her business

loans.name: Samir

texts.en: Samir I. has raised cattle and farmed for 10 years. He has a daughter and the responsibility of providing food for his home. He has been able to improve his family’s financial situation thanks to the excellent care that he has given his animals. Today Samir needs to buy calves to raise so he can raise and sell them at the optimum time. Samir is requesting a loan from AqroInvest Credit Union to buy these animals and raise them so that, in time, their sale can support his family.

loans.use: To purchase four calves

loans.name: Vicente Guerrero 2 Group

texts.es:
La Señora Maricela Zúñiga A. es originaria y vecina D. la Localidad D. Cruz GranD., situada en la Costa Chica del Estado D. Guerrero.
Tiene 30 años es una persona casada con 4 hijos que viven con ella D. 14, 12, 8 y 5 años D. edad, todos sus hijos estudian diferentes grados escolares en la localidad.
DesD. hace 5 años que tiene una pequeña tienda D. venta D. comestibles y artículos D. primera necesidad, su tienda siempre ha sido muy pequeña ya que no contaba con apoyos crediticios, hace 4 meses recibió un crédito D. Fundación Realidad por la cantidad D. 3,000 meses el cual lo pagó en un plazo D. 4 meses y le sirvió para ampliar un poco su tienda, en la actualidad recibió un segundo crédito D. 5,000 pesos tiene intenciones a través D. los créditos D. seguir desarrollando su comercio.
D. esta actividad apoya con el gasto familiar a su esposo para la educación D. sus hijos. Su esposo es empleado D. una compañía D. refrescos, pero su sueldo no alcanza para todos los gastos familiares.
Con el fin D. poder acceder a un crédito es por lo que formaron un grupo D. 10 mujeres D. la misma comunidad, cada una con diferentes actividades productivas ya que es la forma D. adquirir un préstamo con Fundación Realidad.
No contaba con experiencia en créditos, pero esta muy contenta D. los beneficios que ha recibido, y desea seguir con los créditos desarrollando cada vez mas su negocio, también desea seguir con las compañeras D. su grupo con las cuales se siente contenta.

Maricela Zuñiga A.	5,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Dolores M. B.	        3,000.00	Venta D. comestibles 
Lucia A. R.	        2,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Adalberta R. M.	        1,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Agripina R. R.	        8,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Dioema Crisóstomo C.	8,000.00	Venta D. productos naturistas
Paula Y. L.	        6,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Petra D. Jesús Pérez	        8,000.00	Venta D. comestibles
Isabel G. M.	        2,000.00	Venta D. plátanos D. la región
Roberta G. M.	        3,000.00	Venta D. ropa
texts.en:
Sra. Maricela Zúñiga A. is a native and resident of the community of Cruz GranD., which is located in Costa Chica in the State of Guerrero. She is 30 years old, married, and has 4 children (ages 14, 12, 8, and 5). All of them attend school in the community and are in different graD. levels.

For 5 years, Maricela has managed a business selling groceries and basic necessities. Her shop has always been small because she never received the assistance of a loan. Four months ago, she obtained a loan from Fundación Realidad in the amount of 3000 MXN and used it to expand her store a little bit. That loan has been repaid. Today she will receive a second loan of 5000 MXN so that she can continue to develop her business. The income from her store covers her family’s expenses, while her husband’s earnings are used to pay for their children’s education. He is employed at a soft drink company, but his salary is not enough to pay for all of the household expenses.

In order to access a loan, the group had to consist of 10 women from the same community. Each member must engage in a productive business activity, since this is a prerequisite for receiving a loan from Fundación Realidad. With no previous credit experience, these ladies are pleased with the benefits they have received. They hope to continue in their development because they want to be eligible for future business loans. In addition, they are happy to be working with one another and hope they can continue as a group.

The breakdown of the group loan is as follows: Maricela Zuñiga A. requests 5000 MXN to sell food. Dolores M. B. requests 3000 MXN to sell food. Lucia A. R. requests 2000 MXN to sell food. Adalberta R. M. requests 1000 MXN to sell food. Agripina R. R. requests 8000 MXN to sell food. Dioema Crisóstomo C. requests 8000 MXN to sell natural products. Paula Y. L. requests 6000 MXN to sell food. Petra D. Jesús Pérez requests 8000 MXN to sell food. Isabel G. M. requests 2000 MXN to sell regional bananas. Roberta G. M. requests 3000 MXN to sell clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to buy merchandise for their respective businesses

location.town: Cruz Grande, Municipio Florencio Villareal, Estado

loans.name: Souzane

texts.fr: Cette femme a ouvert une boutique de vente de mèches et divers articles comme les biscuits et les bonbons. Elle est mariée et est mère de 03 enfants. Cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans la gestion du foyer. Elle a débuté ce commerce depuis 1999 dans le quartier de Gbégnédji à Lomé. En ce moment elle a besoin d’acheter 25 mèches Curly, 15 mèches Nina et 10 mèches Ondulées. C’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite urgemment un crédit de WAGES. Le prêt lui permettra également d'acheter des articles manquants dans sa boutique comme des bonbons et des biscuits.
texts.en:
This woman opened a shop selling hair extensions and various goods, such as cookies and candy.  She is married and the mother of three children.  This business enables her to do her financial part in managing the home.  She started this business in 1999 in the Gbégnédji district in Lomé.  At this time, she needs to buy 25 Curly hair extensions, 15 Nina hair extensions, and 10 Ondulées hair extensions.  For this reason, she has an urgent request for a WAGES loan.  The loan will also allow her to buy items lacking in her shop, such as candy and cookies.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions and various goods to sell

loans.name: Shahbaz

texts.en:
Shahbaz S. is a young entrepreneur. Seven years ago, he started his own business selling food and home supplies as a way to support his wife and son. With hard work and a lot of effort, he has succeeded in expanding his business. This is also thanks to daily improvement in the quality of the service and products that he offers his clients. 

Shahbaz's son is his motivation for continuing to improve and expand his business. To meet the current demand of his clients, Shahbaz is requesting a loan of 1606 AZN. With your help, Shahbaz will improve the quality of the service he offers his clients and will continue to expand his business. He appreciates the opportunity that your support offers him.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
La señora Ana María J. tiene dos hijo los cuales quiere lo mejor para ellos, a su hija la mayor le está haciendo falta una computadora para realizar las tareas que le encargan en su escuela.
 Pero en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder comprar la computadora y así su hija no tenga que salir a otro lugar a ser sus trabajos de la escuela.
Planea pagar el crédito con el ingreso que obtiene su esposo el señor Francisco Hidalgo como trabajador de una compañía de carros en el departamento de mensajería, este es al la fuente de ingresos de la familia y con el cual una parte será para pagar el crédito.
La señora Ana María ya ha tenido cuatro créditos con FVP los cuales los a pagado puntual mente.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ana María J. has two children for whom she wants the best. Her oldest daughter is in need of a computer in order to complete the assignments given to her at school. Currently, however, she doesn’t not have enough money to purchase a computer so her daughter has to use a computer elsewhere to complete her homework. Ana plans on paying back the loan with the income her husband, Mr. Fracisco Hidalgo, earns as a messenger for an automotive company, as he is the main breadwinner in the family. Mrs. Ana María has taken out four loans with FVP, which she was paid on time.

Translated from Spanish by Maya Wisnievitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a computer for her daughter

loans.name: Jony Alexis

texts.es: El señor Jony Alexis, el tiene 23 años de edad, es soltero y no tiene hijos. El señor tiene un negocio de videojuegos, el cual funciona como una fuente alterna de ingresos para su familia, ya que el labora en la alcaldía. Este negocio empezó hace 3 años con muy poco capital de trabajo con tres maquinas de video juegos, ahora el ya tiene 5 maquinas y desea comprar una más que esta actualizada para que sea más atractivo el acercarse a su negocio. Hace 7 meses tuvo problemas de electricidad, pese a ello se le fundieron 2 maquinas sin embargo es por eso que solicita el financiamiento para  la compra de nuevas maquinas y la reparación de las que se dañaron. Su meta es crecer más en el negocio para tener una mayor estabilidad económica de él y de su familia.
texts.en:
Jony Alexis, 23, is single and does not have any children. He has a video game business, which serves as an alternate source of income for his family. He works in the mayor’s office. He started his business three years ago with a little bit of money from work. He started with three video game machines, and now he has five. He wants to buy one more that is updated. This is so that it will be more attractive to approach his business. Seven months ago he had problems with electricity. Because of this, two machines burned out. That is why he is asking for the loan to buy new machines and repair the ones that were damaged. His goal is to expand the business more in order to have greater economic stability for him and his family

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur  est menuisier dans le quartier de Hédzranawoé à Lomé ; il est marié et a 02 enfants à sa charge. Il a ouvert cet atelier depuis 1990 et dispose d’une longue expérience dans la menuiserie. Il a su fidéliser la plupart de ses clients qui apprécient la qualité de ses meubles. Pour cette raison, il achète très souvent des planches et confectionne des meubles qu’il revend ensuite. Il achète ses planches au Ghana, le pays voisin mais aussi en Côte d’ivoire pour la bonne qualité de leur bois. En ce moment il est en manque de fonds pour commander les planches ; c’est pour cela qu’il a approché WAGES pour pouvoir lancer de nouvelles commandes.
texts.en:
This gentleman is a furniture maker in the Hédzranawoé district in Lomé.  He is married and has two children in his care.  He opened this workshop in 1990 and has extensive experience in carpentry.  He figured out how to earn the loyalty of most of his customers, who appreciate the quality of his work.  For this reason, he buys boards quite often and makes furniture, which he then resells.  He buys his boards in Ghana, the neighboring country, but also in Cote d'Ivoire, for the quality of their wood.  At this time, he lacks the funds for ordering boards.  And so, he has approached WAGES to be able to initiate new orders.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy lumber

loans.name: Yehowa Neme Hwefo Group

texts.en:
Agnes is 49 years old. She is married and the mother of four children. All her children are currently independent. She works hard to support the husband and take care of their home.

Agnes produces and sells palm oil. Palm oil is produced from palm-nut fruits. The palm oil is processed through various stages to obtain the palm oil which is used to prepare many local dishes, like fried fish, local soaps and pastries. She produces and supplies the oil to food vendors who use it to prepare their meals. She also sells the palm fruits to those who need them for further processing. However, her production is on the low side because she doesn't have enough money to afford a processing machine. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of palm fruits. She believes the loan will enable her to save more for her children's education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

Agnes is the leader of a trust bank group called "Yehowa Neme Hwefo," which means "God is my provider." She is sitting in the middle in the group in the  photograph. The members of this group are small traders, food vendors, and farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and provide peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy palm oil and palm nuts fruits in bulk

loans.name: Prince

texts.en:
Prince is a 40-year-old trader. He is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. He is a very resourceful man whose hard work provides a livelihood for the family.
