Morn T., 35, is married with a school-aged child. She resides in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, with her husband and child. Her husband operates his motorbike as a taxi driver, earning an income of US$2 per day.

Mrs. T. is engaged in a business selling various kinds of fruit to her new and existing customers, earning an income of approximately US$6 per day. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. T. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, T. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase more kinds of fruit to stock her stand.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Mok

texts.en:
Mr. Mok S., age 58, is the father of two kids, both of whom are employed in a garment factory. His wife, Klang Chanthou, 43, is a local chef and a housing decorator as well. She appears in the photo.

Mok S. makes a living driving a taxi motorcycle, picking up his passengers in and around his community. He currently earns an average of $4 a day and has been running his service for a long time.

Mok S. hopes to earn additional income by using a Kiva loan as capital to purchase a cultivating machine and will earn fees by renting it to farmers during the farming season.

loans.use: To purchase a cultivating machine to rent to farmers

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
"Wise management of business is necessary to achieve success in life," says Riza. She is married to Jose, who raises hogs while she manages her village store. The couple are blessed with three children: Melanie, 12 years old, a high school student; April Joy, eight years old, an elementary school student; and Hariz, two months old.

Riza would like to fulfill her dreams in life by improving and expanding her store. For this purpose, she would like to borrow additional capital from KIVA lenders in the amount of PHP5,000. She plans to use the loan to buy merchandise for her store in order to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes that her request will be approved so she can generate more income to provide for the welfare of her family.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase more stock

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en: Merlita A. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia City. She is 36 years old, is married, and has three infant children. Merlita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products like rice, spices and more in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Merlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Narcisia

texts.en:
Narcisia sells vegetables, fish and meat in their village. She hopes to improve her business so as to better provide for the needs of her children, especially in terms of their education, and is therefore requesting a loan of PHP5,000.00. Narcisia will use the loan to buy more inventory in order to increase her income.

Residing in the village of Mozzozzin Norte, Sta.Maria Isabela, Narcisia, 24 years old and married to Joseph, a pottery maker in their village, is the mother of two children: Marygrace - four years old, already in pre-school and Joseph Jr. - three years old.

loans.use: Additional capital to increase her inventory

loans.name: Erlinda T.

texts.en:
Erlinda has been two years in her livestock business and her net profit per month is Php 3,000. Sometimes she also sells vegetables in their village for additional income.

Now Erlinda is asking for a loan of Php 8,000 to strengthen her livestock business in order to improve her family's living conditions. She plans to use the loan to renovate her pigpens for provide better shelter for her hogs. She also wants to buy young piglets to raise.

Erlinda’s family resides in the village of Culalabat, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is married to a farmer named Nicanor Jr. and their marriage is blessed with four children who are: Flordeliza, Sherwin, Darwin, and Rodalyn, two of whom are already married. She wants to improve her business and she also wants to support her children in their education.

loans.use: To renovate her pigpens and to purchase some piglets

loans.name: Chhun's Group

texts.en:
This is a small loan that has been requested by two low-income people. The group’s leader, Mrs. Chhun K., age 41, is a local vegetable grower. As another source of family income, Chhun K.’s husband works as a vehicle trader. He also goes to buy vehicles from people who live in rural areas and sells to other people to gain a profit. He typically earns an average of $5 per day.

Chhun K. currently faces difficulty with irrigating her crop because her farm is located far from the water system. Therefore, she would like to ask for a loan to buy a water pump.

The other borrower is Mrs. S., a farmer, who is asking for a loan to support her farming business.

loans.use: To buy a pump for irrigation

loans.name: Morm

texts.en:
Morm R. is 41 years old and resides in Takeo province with her husband (shown in the photo) and eight of her children. Six of the children are in school and two are too young to attend.

Morm R. is a farmer who is able to make about US$2 of profit each day. Her husband is a recycler and also raises chickens. He typically makes around US$3 per day. Morm R. is asking for a loan of US$700 to purchase a motorbike her husband needs to transport recycled items.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband's business

loans.name: Marjolyn

texts.en: Marjolyn O. lives in the village of Prk. Makawili, Barangay Balaring, Silay City, Negros Occidental. She is 49 years old and married to Ramon O., who currently works as a fish vendor in their local community. The couple is blessed with four children who are 16 to 26 years old, with the three younger kids still attending school. Her most cherished aspiration is to provide her children, through her own efforts and hard work, with a good life and a good education that will empower them to have gainful work and a bright future. When Marjolyn’s children were so much younger, she realized that her husband's income would not be sufficient to sustain the growing needs of their family, especially in relation to her dream of sending her children to college. This is why she decided to go into business for herself by starting a general store. In 2001, when Marjolyn wanted to expand her business, she decided to join NWTF-Project Dungganon. From the loan assistance she received, she was able to enlarge her product offerings and thereby increase her income capacity, which now averages PHP 8,000 net profit. Her increased income enabled her to invest in other businesses as the years went by and now she has a fishing boat that provides additional income for her and her family. For her last loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marjolyn borrowed PHP 15,000 which she used as additional income for both her general store and her fishing business. Now that she has fully repaid that loan within its loan term, she is again applying to renew her loan for the same amount of PHP 15,000 to use as working capital for her two businesses. She hopes to be able to buy some household appliances and have her house repaired with the income she earns from this loan. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store and fishing business

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma sells snacks in the school canteen in Rizal Santiago City. She is 35 years old and married to Felimon. Felimon is a driver in their village.They are blessed with four children: Geraldine (13 years old, 2nd year high school), Gerald Mon (11 years old, Grade V pupil), Erskene Jake (6 years old, Grade I pupil) and Kristine Joy (four months old). Due to the large size of their household, the income they are generating is not enough to meet their basic needs and maintain their businesses. That’s the reason Gemma would like to obtain a loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos.

According to Gemma, she would like to improve her business, and she wants to buy additional merchandise so that she can generate more income for her family's needs. Her husband is in full support of her business. This couple works hard to double the income they generate. She hopes that her loan will be granted, because it will be very helpful to buy more snacks to sell.

loans.use: Additional capital to improve her snack vending business

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Leng C., 51, has a business making and selling brooms at the local market of Takeo province. The brooms are made from a kind of long grass which grows in the forest. Leng C. learned how to make brooms from her neighbors and she started doing this business in 2000. She earns around $3 US each day. Her husband is a wedding chef and makes $1 US every day. This couple has two children, both employed as garment factory workers.

Leng C. told a loan officer that every month she needs to spend around $30 US on food and $5 US on utilities. She is asking for a loan from Kiva via CREDIT, the local partner, to purchase long grass in bulk. This will save money and allow her to make more brooms. She plans to distribute the brooms to other small sellers. In the future, if possible, she wants to have a small truck to transport the brooms.

loans.use: To make brooms

loans.name: Ednalyne

texts.en:
“If there is no pain, there is no gain” is a guiding principle of a hardworking mother like Ednalyne V. of Barangay Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. Her husband is Marlon V. and they are blessed with three children. She and her husband help each other to earn a living and support the schooling of their children. As a fruit of their patience and sacrifices, their eldest child has graduated from college and is presently working in one of the well known companies in Manila while the two youngest are presently studying in tertiary level.

Ednalyne’s husband cultivates their farm by planting rice and some vegetables while Ednalyne is engaged in selling fish and frozen foods. She acquires her product from Solano Public Market and sells it in their village on a retail basis. They earn an average income of P 700 a week which they use to acquire their daily basic needs and to finance the schooling of their children.

Since their income is not sufficient for the needs of the family Ednalyne wants to earn more income to meet their needs. So she wants to borrow additional capital of P 8,000 to be used in improving their small business. They believe that with the use of this financial assistance, they can improve their business and earn more income.

loans.use: To buy more goods to retail

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet manages a sari-sari store (community-based store) and also she sells vegetables and fruits. Janet is married to Sanny Boy who is a technician in their village. This couple works hard for the improvement of their businesses. Janet would like to borrow 5,000 Philippine pesos from Kiva lenders. She will use her loan to buy additional merchandise such as vegetables, fruits and basic commodities for her store. This money could really help her to expand and improve her community-based store. She will be thankful if this loan is approved.

loans.use: Capital to purchase additional merchandise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Sun V., 28, is married and lives with two of her children in the Takeo province. She grows and sells rice, typically making about US $5 each day. Her husband is a construction worker who specializes in building houses. On average, he makes US $3.30 per day.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have made this a tough economic year for many Cambodians, Sun V. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase rice with the intention of reselling it and turning over a profit. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a way to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: purchasing rice to sell

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan L., 28, pictured with her husband, is married and lives with two of her children in the Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers; additionally, they make cow bells to sell at the local market. They typically make about US $2 each day. 

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have made this a tough economic year for many Cambodians, Chan L. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US $800 to purchase materials and tools to make more cow bells. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: purchasing materials and tools to make more cow bells

loans.name: Uok

texts.en:
Mrs. Uok Seom is a villager from Kor Village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. In this farming she now faces a small problem because her field has infertile soil. To solve this problem she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizer to support her field. She would use the rest of the loan to buy a pump to water the field.

Mrs. Uok Seom’s husband, Mr. Sok Son, helps her with the farming. He is on the left in the photo. Mrs. Uok Seom has three children who are all attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her field and an irrigation pump

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony C.'s guiding principle is "time is gold." He is an ordinary villager in Baculud Iguig, Cagayan. He is 28 years old, single and lives with his parents. Anthony C. is well known for being a hardworking man in their village.

Anthony and his family members farm; this helps provide them with income. In order to help his parents provide for the daily needs of their family however, Anthony decided to start and manage his own village store. He has been doing this for five years now.

Anthony currently wants to borrow PHP 10,000 for the maintenance of his business.

loans.use: maintaining his business

loans.name: Lieng Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. Lieng Sim S. lives in Ang Svay Chek village in Takeo province. She is 26 years old and the mother of two children aged two and five years old.

Lieng Sim and her husband, Mr. Ur Peng Leom (see photo), breed pigs at her house. Since this business is going so well, she would like to expand it. She is asking for a loan through Angkor Microfinance Kampuchea (AMK) to buy more piglets.

loans.use: To buy more piglets.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Pov C., 36, is a widow with four school-aged children. She resides in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, with her children. To make a living, she sells bananas, potatoes, and sugar cane juice to her new and existing customers; she earns an income of approximately US $8 per day. This is her fourth loan from Kiva’s partner, CREDIT. Ms. C. is seeking to improve her standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, C. is asking for a loan of US $700 to purchase more goods to expand her business.

loans.use: purchasing more goods to expand her business

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Yun P., 40, is married and lives with four of her children in the Takeo province. She is a farmer and makes cow bells to sell at the local market; she typically makes about US $1.60 each day. Her husband is a construction worker who specializes in building houses. He typically makes US $3.30 per day. 

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have made this a tough economic year for many Cambodians, Yun P. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US $1000, which her husband will use to run a motor-taxi. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: running a motor-taxi

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
Som N. makes a living selling chicken and pork porridge to her new and longstanding customers. She earns approximately $2 US per day. She is 51 years old and married with five children. They live in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. Her daughter operates a business designing and sewing clothes, earning $2 US per day to help cover the family's expenses.

Mrs. N. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, N. is asking for a loan of $1000 US to purchase a motorbike to more easily commute to the market to buy goods. The motorbike will also help one of her family members to travel to work more easily and cut back on using public transportation services. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. The photo shows N. with her son.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Cosme

texts.en: Cosme C. is from the village of Toril, Panalsalan. He is 55 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Cosme owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over thirty-five years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month. In 2006, Cosme joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Cosme is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be his 5th from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Mrs. Khmao Phan Village Bank Group

texts.en:
These seventeen villagers who make up the town bank’s loan group all live in Prek Reang village in Kandal province. Mrs. Khmoa P. was selected by the group members to be the village bank president. She is 33 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attending the local school; her youngest is two years old. Her husband, Mr. Roeun Ry, is both a fisherman and a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he cultivates rice.

Khmoa breeds pigs and sells fish in the local market. She is requesting a loan through Angkor Microfinance Kampuchea (AMK)to buy more piglets for breeding and fishnets for fishing.

loans.use: To buy piglets and fishnets.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann C.'s main source of income comes from raising and selling coconuts in her community. She is 34 years old, married and has one small child. She is from the village of Mangidkid, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. Mary Ann has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Mary Ann joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Mary Ann has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC which was used to invest in expanding her business. Mary Ann is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional copra (coconut) to sell. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional copra (coconut)

loans.name: Ceril

texts.en: Ceril L. is from the village of Baybay, Panalsalan. She is 33 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Ceril owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Ceril joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Ceril is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase a fishing boat. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Enkhbold

texts.en: Enkhbold D. is 27 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Tuv province of central Mongolia. His daughter, 6, attends a local primary school and his son, 2, stays at home. D. operates a stove and scrap-metal business in his town. He began as a scrap-metal purchaser in 2004 and since then, has expanded his business by also building stoves. D.’s wife purchases scrap metal from people in his town and then he transports it to Erdenet city to sell to the recycling plant. They operate their scrap-metal business from land next to their house, where his wife purchases the metal. D. operates the stove building/welding side of their business from a shop downtown. He wants to be able to afford an apartment for his family one day where they will be more comfortable. D. is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan in order to be able to purchase more scrap metal, welding materials and cement blocks for his business. XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team. To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more scrap metal, welding materials and cement blocks for his business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more piglets and some chickens to raise

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn L. is from the village of Hinaplanan, Iligan City. She is 58 years old. Evelyn is widowed. To make a living, Evelyn operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2008, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Evelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Fedila

texts.en:
Fedila M. is from the village of D'BAN, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 58 years old. Fedila is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Fedila operates a service recycling scrap metal. The main source of income for the business comes from selling scrap metal and other products like bottles and plastic. Fedila has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2008, Fedila joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fedila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. Fedila is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to buy additional scrap metal for sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Fedila from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional scrap metal to sell

loans.name: Mr. Kha Roeng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Kha R. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a fisherman. He is 34 years old and the father of two children who are attending the local school. His wife, Mrs. Heng Tho, is employed in a garment factory. In his fishery, he faces an obstacle because he does not have fishnets which is affecting his income. Thus, he decided to request a loan to buy more fishnets for his fishery. He hopes to increase his income and improve his family's life with this loan.

Mr. Kha R. is the president of this village bank which consists of 14 people located in Prek Reang village in Kandal province. The members will use the loan for different purposes.

loans.use: To buy more fishnets for his fishery

loans.name: Baasai

texts.en:
Baasai G. is 45 years old, and he lives with his wife and son in Hovd province in western Mongolia. His son, Enhbat, is 11 years old and attends a local secondary school. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent.

With his wife's help, G. operates a coal-selling business in his town. Specifically, he purchases coal directly from local mines, and he transports the purchased coal (by using his large Russian truck) back to his town. His wife then helps him sell the coal to various local businesses and individuals for use in heating. G. has operated this business since 2000; by doing so, he has gained a great deal of experience over the years. He explains that he has a large customer base, including many loyal clients, and that he hopes to purchase a larger truck in the future to keep up with growing demand. In fact, he notes that his old Russian truck is outdated, and that individuals with newer, larger, more fuel-efficient trucks are able to generate higher earnings than he can, which is why he would like a new truck. In the meantime, though, G. is simply requesting a loan in the amount of 1,000,000 tugrug (~$725 USD) to make necessary repairs to his truck and to purchase petrol so that he can transport more coal.

XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first Kiva loan in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but it also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale, and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the maturity of their loans. This practice not only allows borrowers to realize a financial gain, but also encourages them to save money

loans.use: To expand and improve his coal-selling business by making necessary repairs to his truck and by purchasing petrol

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarom S. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Aside from this plantation, she is a pig breeder. She is 35 years old and the mother of four children: three of them are enrolled in the local school and the youngest is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Men Nen, owns a rice mill which the villagers hire to mill rice. He also uses the rice to make wine to sell. They live in Doem Rom Del village in Takeo province.

Now Mrs. Sarom S. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides, a piglet and pig feed. She hopes to improve her business and provide a better life for her family.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides, a piglet and pig feed

loans.name: Rentsen

texts.en:
Rentsen B. is 19 years old, and she lives with her retired mother in Kharhorin, the capital city of the ancient Mongolian empire, which is where she has lived since she was born.

B. operates a jewelry-selling business in her town. She is a young entrepreneur; in fact, she just recently started her business this past July. More specifically, she sells a variety of jewelry, most of which are made of silver. She is working hard to grow and establish her business in her community; however, her product inventory is low, and she has little available capital to purchase new items to sell. B. considers herself a shy person by nature, but she works diligently to succeed with her business and to improve her business skills. She has a great deal of hope for her business' future. B. is requesting a loan in the amount of 500,000 tugrug (approximately $375 USD) to purchase wholesale silver items for resale purposes.

XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first Kiva loan in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but it also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale, and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the maturity of their loans. This practice not only allows borrowers to realize a financial gain, but also encourages them to save money.

loans.use: To expand her inventory by purchasing additional silver items

loans.name: Yuth

texts.en:
Mrs. Yuth H. and her husband, Mr. Hang Hean, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. For cultivating rice, they have some problems because their field has infertile soil, and they do not have enough money to buy gasoline for their plow. Thus, Mrs. Yuth H. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides and gasoline for the plow for her farming.

Mrs. Yuth H. is a 53-year-old mother of three children: one is employed in a garment factory, while another is a farmer, and the last one is attending the local school. They live in Doem Rom Del village in Takeo province.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides and gasoline for a plow

loans.name: Arslan

texts.en:
Arslan M. is 45 years old, and she lives with her husband and children in Khovd province in western Mongolia. She has five sons and one daughter. Her oldest son lives and works in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city; her two middle sons live with their father in the countryside; and her two youngest sons and daughter are students at local schools.

M. operates a small boot-making and boot-repair business in her town. She makes durable boots, which she trades with herders in the surrounding countryside. As many herders do not have cash to purchase new boots, she trades her products for a variety of dairy products and animals. She then sells these dairy products at the local market in her town for a profit. Her husband and two of her sons live and raise the animals they acquire in the countryside. The family uses the animals for meat and furs.

M. started her business in 2008 yet she has quickly found success. Indeed, her business has enabled her to maintain both of her family's homes and to ensure that her family has a high standard of living. M. is a very hard-working, sociable, and business-minded person. She always looks for ways to increase her earnings and to improve her business. For instance, she explains that, last summer, she experimented by starting a retail grocery business, which was quite profitable. She notes that she will continue to produce boots in the hope that one of her children can start a grocery business in the future. In this way, she is trying to do many things in order to provide for her children. M. is requesting a loan in the amount of 500,000 tugrug (approximately $375 USD) to purchase materials such as felt boots, leather, and rubber for her boot-making business.

XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first Kiva loan in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but it also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale, and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the maturity of their loans. This practice not only allows borrowers to realize a financial gain, but also encourages them to save money.

loans.use: To expand and improve her boot-making business by purchasing materials such as felt boots, leather, and rubber

loans.name: Pach

texts.en:
Mrs. Pach S. was born in 1965 and lives in Andoung Samreth village in Takeo province. Cambodia. She is Khmer noodle seller. Her husband, Mr. Tom Sarath, is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare field where he cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a duck breeder. Since his poultry business is going well, he wants to expand it by purchasing 625 more ducklings for breeding to earn more income. Mrs. Pach S. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. 

This couple has four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, one is a duck breeder, one is a laborer, and the other one attends the local school.

loans.use: To buy 625 ducklings

loans.name: Sharivkhan

texts.en:
Sharivkhan K. is 43 years old and lives with his wife and five children live in a house in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. Two of his children attend university while the younger three children all attend a local secondary school.

K. owns his own ironwork/metalwork business where he produces such items as stoves, stove pipes, smokestacks and horseshoes. He began his business in 2001, but learned the trade many years ago as an apprentice to his grandfather. After K. produces the items, his wife sells them at the local market. He says, “My dream is to expand my business and establish a workshop of my own. I also want my children to go to university and be well educated.”

K. is requesting a 300,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase raw materials for making stoves for the upcoming winter months.


About XacBank:
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for making stoves

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia M. lives in the village Prk. Bayong, Barangay Balintawak, Escalante City. She is 58 years old and married to Glecerio M. who presently works as a dental technician. Glecerio used to be the sole breadwinner for the family, but in spite of all his hard work, his income was just not enough to cover the expenses, especially the education-related expenses of their five children. Because both Cecilia and Glecerio aspired to a better life for their children, it was their dream to send them all to finish college. Because of her sewing and dressmaking skills, Cecilia started accepting sewing jobs from a few regular customers until, by word of mouth and recommendations, her roster of clients grew. To have more working capital for her growing business, Cecilia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 and, because of the additional capital infusion, she took the opportunity to open a rice retailing business. Now her combined business income earns her an average monthly profit of PHP 7,000, which has made a big impact on their quality of life. Today, Cecilia’s children, who are between 16 and 31 years of age, are well on their way to achieving Cecilia’s and Glecerio's aspirations for them. As her businesses continues to grow, Cecilia uses her loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon to sustain the capital required to operate them. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000 was used to maintain the inventory level of her rice retailing business as well as to purchase sewing supplies. Now on her 13th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to continue sustaining her businesses. She intends to use the income for the education of her children and to save for their future. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sewing and rice retail businesses

loans.name: Saroeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeurn K. lives in Andoung Samreth village in Takeo province, Cambodia. She owns a piece of land where she grows rice. She is also a pig breeder. Now she wants to expand her business; thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets, pig food, rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticides to support the plantation. Her husband, Mr. Pak Sokha, uses the rice to make wine to sell to earn income. 

Mrs. Saroeurn K. is 27 years old and the mother of two children, the older one attends the local school but the younger one is too young. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy piglets, pig food, rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticides

loans.name: Tim

texts.en: Tim C., 27, pictured with her husband, is married and lives with two of her children in Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$1 each day. To earn more profit, her husband also works collecting recyclable items to sell at the recycling plant and makes US$2.50 every day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have created a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Tim C. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase fertilizer and a trailer to transport recyclable items. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and a trailer

loans.name: Pech

texts.en: Pech S. is 41 years old and lives with her husband and two of her children in Takeo province. To earn a living, she buys and sells bananas at the local market and typically makes US$2.30 profit every day. Her husband is a construction foreman. On average, he makes US$8 every day. Two of the children are in school. Pech S. is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey N. lives in Andoung Samreth village in Takeo province, Cambodia. She owns a small grocery store. Her husband, Mr. San Sok, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he grows rice. He is also a pig breeder. Since his pig-breeding business is going well, he wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Srey N. decided to ask for a loan to buy six more piglets and pig food for her husband’s business. 

Mrs. Srey N. is 51 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is a driver and the other is employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy six piglets and pig food

loans.name: Pom

texts.en: Pom B., 20, is married and lives with her young child in Takeo province. She makes rice wine and raises pigs, making around US$10 in revenue each day, while her husband works as a moto-taxi driver. Her husband makes about US$4 each day, however they must also support her mother at home. Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also been a factor in making the price of rice very high. Pom B. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more rice to make rice wine and raise pigs. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase rice

loans.name: Nheurng

texts.en:
Mrs. Nheurng K. is a villager in Andoung Samreth village in Takeo province, Cambodia. She owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces some problems because her field is far from an irrigation system and the soil is not very fertile. Thus, Mrs. Nheurng K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a water machine, fertilizer, and pesticides to support her farm. 

She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's standard of living. She is a 40-year-old widow with four children, one of whom is a driver while the others attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy a water machine, fertilizer, and pesticides

loans.name: Samoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Samoeurn M. lives in Andoung Samreth village in Takeo province, Cambodia. She owns a plot of land where she cultivates both rice and vegetables. She also breeds ducks. Since her poultry business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing seven more ducklings and duck food to support her breeding business. 

Her husband, Mr. Sen Sep, is a laborer who has been hired by the village to plow the field and to pump water to sell. Mrs. Samoeurn M. is 42 years old and the mother of seven children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, one is a farmer, and the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy seven ducklings and duck food

loans.name: Kang

texts.en: Kang H. is 54 years old and lives in Takeo province with his wife. He is a village chief who makes a living of US$1 per day. His wife has been a professional tailor since 2000. On average, she is able to make about US$1.30 per day. This couple has three children, one of whom is in school and two are workers. Kang H. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike for the family’s transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Chhoeun

texts.en: Chhoeun S., 28, is a widow and resides with her young child and her mother in Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker who is able to make about US$3 per day, while her mother is a weaver and makes US$4 per day. Chin Sokoeun would like to take out a loan of US$500 to raise cows.

loans.use: To buy cows

loans.name: Toem

texts.en:
Mrs. Toem S. lives in Andoung Samreth village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. Now she is requesting a loan to buy a water pump, fertilizers, and pesticides to support her rice field to make the crop more productive.

Toem S. is 66 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are motorbike repairers, one is a construction worker and the other two are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Koem Roeun, is a construction worker. He is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy an irrigation pump, fertilizers and pesticides for her rice field

loans.name: Chhan

texts.en: Chann S. is 28 years old and lives with his wife in Takeo province. He is a construction worker building houses who is able to make a living of US$8 each day. His wife works as a garment factory worker. She typically makes US$3 per day. Chan S. would like to take out a loan of US$450 to purchase construction tools to assist in his work.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda B. is from the village of Calabayan Ozamiz City. She is 28 years old. Rosalinda is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda works in a family member's business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized lemon retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling lemon products in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Rosalinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rosalinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and for daily needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sirojiddin

texts.ru: Сироджиддин Бабаев проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст 34 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Сироджиддин более 5 лет работает по своей специальности "учителем". Помимо этого он более 9 лет занимается животноводством. Он откармливает и продает скот. Кредит просит для покупки скота и корма.
texts.en:
Sirojiddin Babev lives in Kurgan-Tube. He is 34 and married with three children. For over five years, Sirojiddin has been a teacher. In addition to this job, he has been raising livestock for over 9 years. He fattens and sells the livestock for a profit. Sirojiddin is requesting a loan to purchase animals and feed.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase feed and animals

loans.name: Abdulfatoh

texts.ru: Исломов Абдулфатох проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст 40 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Абдулфатох по специальности "учитель", но по специальности не работал. Он более 10 лет занимается торговлей, бизнесом. Абдулфатох имеет магазин, в котором торгует автозапчастями. Кредит просит для увеличения товараборота, т.е. закупа автозапчастей.
texts.en:
Abdulfatoh I. lives in Qurgan-Tube. He is 40 years old and married with three children. Abdulfatoh was trained as a teacher, but has not worked in the profession. For more than 10 years, he has been in business. Abdulfatoh has a store where he sells auto parts. He has applied for a loan to increase his sales turnover by purchasing more parts.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase auto parts

loans.name: Hoshim

texts.ru: Ахунов Хошим проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст 42 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Хошим имеет высшее образование. Он более 9 лет занимается торговлей стройматериалов на рынке. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Hoshim A. lives in Qurgan-Tube. He is 42 years old and married with three children. His wife is a homemaker. Hoshim has a university education. For over 9 years, he has been selling building materials at the market. He has requested a loan to increase his sales turnover.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase sales turnover

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 33 years old, married and blessed with four children. One of them is already in high school while three are still at the elementary level.  

Agnes is a retailer of goods in the school canteen in their village.  Aside from this, she is also engaged in the hog raising business.  She would like to borrow a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5,000 that she needs to develop her business.  Her husband's source of income is farming and he also helps her in managing her hog raising business.  

Agnes dreams of developing her business to sustain the immediate needs of their family, especially in sending her children to school.  She believes that with her business, she can fulfill her plans in life.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Mahmadrajab

texts.ru: Яров Махмадрачаб проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст 51 год. Женат, имеет 8 детей. Два старших сына занимаются животноводством. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Махмадрачаб по специальности "агрономом" работает более 13 лет. Помимо этого он занимается сельским хозяйством. В основном он выращивает пшеницу для продажи. Кредит просит для покупки семян и удобрений, чтобы посеить новый урожай.
texts.en:
Y. Mahmadrajab lives in Qurgan-Tube. He is 51 years old and married with eight children. His two oldest sons raise animals and his wife is a homemaker. Y. has been an agronomist for over 13 years. In addition to this job, he has a small farm. His main activity is cultivating wheat to sell. Y. has requested a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer to sow the new crop.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina C. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 38 years old. Gina is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a mini restaurant. The main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. Gina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. Gina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional materials for making food. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Gina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials for making food

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Hurshed

texts.ru: Солиев Хуршед проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст 34 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Хуршед более 7 лет занимается земледелием. Он выращивает пшеницу и картофель. Одну часть продает а другую оставляет для употребления. Кредит просит, чтобы купить удобрения семена, для нового посева.
texts.en:
Hurshed S., 34, lives in the city of Kurgan-Tyube. He has a wife and five children. Hurshed has been a farmer for over seven years, growing wheat and potatoes. One part of the crop he sells, while saves the other part for future use. He is asking for a loan in order to buy fertilizer and seeds for a new sowing.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To plant a new crop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
"Everything you do, put God first," says Rosita.  She is 47 years old and married to Emilio Sr. who works as a mechanic in their village. This couple are blessed with two children: Emeerose, 24 years old, college graduate and now working as an Overseas Filipino Worker (OFW) and the youngest is Emilio IV, 13 years old, high school student.

Rosita is a store owner and at the same time managing a mini carinderia or eatery in the village of Nagassican. Her husband is in full support of her business. She is thankful because her family has cooperation. Rosita would like to improve and expand her small businesses so she can encourage more costumers to buy at her store. With her desire to pursue her business plans, she is now requesting a loan amount of PHP5000 from KIVA lenders. She hopes that the lenders will support her in having a more comfortable way of living.

loans.use: Additional capital for business expansion

loans.name: Shiella

texts.en:
Shiella G. is from the village of Sulipat, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old. Shiella is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Shiella operates her family's business of raising and selling coconut crops in the local community. Shiella has been engaged in the business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

Shiella joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shiella is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional coconuts for resale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Shiella from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional coconuts for resale

loans.name: Ella

texts.en:
Ella R. is a vegetable farmer and vendor in her village and in some other municipalities near her village. She is 54 years old and she has been in business for 15 years. Her husband, Cesar, is a farmer. They are blessed with three children. Her first child has graduated and is taking electrical engineering courses, the second is still in school and the youngest is still an infant. Ella and her husband are helping each other to plant and sell vegetables.

Ella expanded her planted vegetable site in her fields. She needs capital to maintain her business. Her business contributes a lot to supporting her family's needs. In this regard, she is asking to borrow 5,000 PHP for the maintenance of her vegetable farm and to buy the necessary fertilizer and seeds.

loans.use: Farm maintenance and purchase of fertilizer and seeds

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Isabella

texts.en:
Isabella is a very strong lady and is the bread winner for her family. She is married with five children (three girls and two boys), and her husband is unemployed. 

Isabella was a farmer before she ventured into the cereal business. She has been in this business for 23 years now, and wants to expand in order to be able to meet her huge financial obligations. She wants to borrow KES 50,000 to increase her inventory of cereals. She operates in a market where she has rented a stand. Her major challenge is that she operates alone, and it's tough. 

Her dream is to see her kids get the best education. Five years from now, she wants to run a wholesale store. She describes herself as a hardworking person.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of maize, beans and groundnuts

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em P. is 25 years old and a resident of Pursat province, Cambodia. She makes a living raising pigs, which she sells for slaughter four months after starting to raise them. She has been raising pigs for about three years and is currently earning around $3 a day.

Em P. is married with two children and both are going to the local public school. She is married to Chea Cheat, 23 years old, who works with her in raising pigs. Em P. and her husband are shown in the photo.

Because her pig-raising business is the main source of family income, Em P. applied for a loan to purchase more piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Farming is the main source of income of Maricel and her husband Pilo. They have been gifted with a daughter named Eugene - nine years old.

Aside from rice farming, Maricel also managing her small general store to have an additional source of income. She would like to buy some additional groceries for her store but her capital is insufficient. That’s why she would like financial assistance of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders. She hopes that her requested loan will be profitable so that she can generate a bigger income for her family needs.

Maricel and her husband strive hard to improve their way of living.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her store

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes G. sells goods in her general store, which is located at her house at the village of Santiago, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She is 52 years old and married to her loving husband, Erwin, who is 38 years old. The couple is blessed with two children named Edna and April Joy, both of whom are studying in school. Edna is a third year high school student, while April Joy is presently a Grade IV student.

For two years, the main source of income for Lourdes is through her store, thus she really values it. She wants to continuously manage her store and she is requesting a loan amounting to 5,000 PHP from Kiva lenders as her additional working capital. She wants to purchase additional commodities for her store, such as canned goods and soft drinks. She really aims to increase her income, especially to pay for the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase additional items for resale

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna C. is from the village of Talisay. She is 51 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Myrna owns and operates a food stall, selling variety of snacks in the school and in the local community. She is just starting this business. The two students included in the picture are Myrna's customers. In 2006, Myrna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from PMPC. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 7th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her grandchildren. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Califonia Group

texts.en:
Editruda C. started a secretarial service business in 2009. She is 45 years old and a widow with five children. She works daily from 8 am until 7 pm. She is able to make a monthly profit of $96. This will be Editruda’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She hopes to get a loan to buy binding and laminating machines.

Editruda will share this loan with her group, "Califonia", which has 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable for paying back their loans. In the picture, Editruda is third from the right (and second from the left) in the front row.

loans.use: To buy laminating and binding machines

loans.name: Oun

texts.en:
To earn a living, Oun M. owns a motor to buy fresh fish in bulk from fisherman. He sells the fish to retailers who take them to the market. Oun M. was born in 1960 and his wife, Ya Khoeun, is age 30. They live together in Pursat Province. He typically generates an income of $5 each day to contribute to his family. His wife is a cake seller. In addition, this couple also cultivates rice during the growing season. The family takes care of three school-age children. Oun M. is looking for a loan to use as capital to sustain the growth of his fish selling business. 
The two people shown in the photo are Mr. Oun M. and his wife.

loans.use: To sustain the growth of a fish sellling business

loans.name: Merlina

texts.en:
Merlina operates a transportation business, and she also had a retail store but it has been closed for one year now. She would like a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos to use for repairs and maintenance of her motorcycle and to reopen her small retail store in order to earn more income.

Merlina is 51 years old and she is married to Romeo E.. The couple is blessed with four children: their eldest is a housekeeper, age 27; followed by a teacher, age 22; next to her is a college student, age 16; and their youngest is a high school student, age 14 years old. They are presently living in the village of Pinoma, Cauayan City. Their house is located near the rice farm and along the village road. She hopes and prays that Kiva lenders will grant her requested loan so she can manage her budget and have a stable business.

loans.use: Repairs and maintenace of her motorcycle and to reopen her retail store

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma A. owns and operates a specialized sari-sari retail store selling different products and gasoline in her community. She is 32 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Bitibut, Sapang Dalaga, Mis. Occ. Wilma has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2008, Wilma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC which was used to invest in expanding her business. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ruth Nanteza's Group

texts.en:
Ruth has a wooden store where she sells charcoal. She sells to all kinds of people, both retail and wholesale. She works seven days a week. She serves an average of 25 customers a day. Her major business challenges include thieves and the rainy season, because she works from an open place in a muddy area, which hinders her customers' ability to reach her. She doesn’t incur additional transport costs to and from her suppliers, because she buys from local suppliers who get charcoal from villages.

Ruth is a 58 year old married woman with four children between the ages of 18 and 30. One of her children goes to school and the rest are working. She owns a four-room house where she lives with seven people. Ruth also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water, and they get three meals a day. Ruth's monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

Ruth has been in her business for 30 years and with MCDT for five years – now on her twelfth loan working with the same group mates. Ruth joined MCDT to increase her capital because it is near her home. Ruth wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She is hoping to see her business get bigger and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Cathy

texts.en:
Cathy owns and manages a small store in her village. She says, “Through humility and patience you can achieve success in life.” She is married to Alfredo, a farmer, and they have five children: Karen (20 years old, college undergraduate), Precy (19 years old), Alfredo (17 years old), Kathleen (3 years old) and Kristine (one month old).

According to her, improving her sari-sari store is what she wants to do. She is working hard to double her income and improve her business. But, due to the high cost of commodities, the income she generates is just enough to meet their daily needs. For this reason, she is asking for financial support from Kiva lenders with a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos. This money will be used to purchase more groceries. She hopes that the loan she is requesting will be approved.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries

loans.name: Bonalyn

texts.en:
Bonalyn is already 25 years old and is married to Alexander who is a tricycle driver within their village of Quezon, San Isidro. They are gifted with a daughter named Shane who is four years old now.

Bonalyn is a retailer of electronic cellphone loads and at the same time she is a dealer of cosmetics products. She would like to purchase all the orders of her customers but she lacks capital. That’s the reason why she would like to borrow additional capital of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders. The amount that she is requesting will be utilized in buying products and some of this amount will be used in her electronic cellphone loading business.

Bonalyn is praying that her business will become profitable and productive.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en: Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Hadija A. R. from Morogoro. She is married with three children between the ages of 3 and 8. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent because his parents can’t take care of him. Since 2000, Hadija has been running a mama lishe (a local restaurant or café). In Tanzania, this usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all-local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), plantains (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. Hadija works at the business for 13 to 16 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. She is requesting a loan of 300,000 Tsh in order to purchase additional ingredients in bulk. In the future, she plans to open another business. Hadija thanks you for your support! About SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Julfa

texts.en:
Julfa V. is from the village of Bitibut, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Julfa owns and operates a "sari-sari" (variety) store, selling different daily-use product in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. Julfa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas P., age 56, lives in the province of Pursat, which is the best territory for farming. She is a married woman who has given birth to one child who is married and has already started a new home.

Meas P. and her husband own a big farm that they inherited from their grandmother. They grow various crops as well as raise many pigs on it.

Meas P. hopes to have cow for her farming business but she doesn't have enough money to buy one. So she decided to request a loan from Kiva's partner HKL to be used to buy a cow for plowing their land. She will use the rest of the loan for pig-raising.

loans.use: To buy a cow for plowing her land and to use for pig-raising

loans.name: Nellie

texts.en:
Nellie is married to Manuel M. and they are blessed with three children.

Nellie is vending frozen food such as longganisa or sausage and tocino (a cured meat product native to the Philippines, usually made out of pork and similar to ham and bacon). She sells her products within their village.

Nellie wants to purchase additional frozen food to be able to satisfy the demands of her customers. In this regard, she is asking for financial support from Kiva lenders for her business improvement and additional stocks of frozen foods. She would be thankful if her requested loan of PHP 4,000 is approved.

Nellie dreams of becoming a successful businesswoman someday so that she could also generate a bigger income for her family’s needs and for her security when she gets weak.

loans.use: To buy more frozen food to sell

loans.name: Lukia Sekaana's Group

texts.en:
Lukia, a 40-year-old married mother of three children between 8 and 20 years of age, all attending school, owns and resides in a five-roomed house with seven people, as she takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day. Lukia's monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. She also incurs transport costs going to and from Owino market, one of the biggest markets in Uganda, where she has a shop selling used clothes.

Working seven days a week, Lukia receives an average of 30 customers a day. Her major business challenges include thieves, the rainy season, and seasonality. During the rainy season she moves door to door, which reduces customer volume. She has been in this business for 15 years and with MCDT for five years, now servicing her twelfth loan working with the same group mates. Lukia joined MCDT because it was near her home and offered the opportunity for her to increase her capital. Lukia wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes and aspires to expand her business and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothing

loans.name: Annabella

texts.en:
Annabella J.'s main source of income comes from making and selling native delicacies in her community. She is 34 years old, married and has five school-age children. They are from the town of Magcamiguing, Calamba, Mis. Occ. Annabella has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Annabella joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Annabella is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase equipment for making food. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for making food

loans.name: Marciana

texts.en:
Marciana M.'s main source of income comes from making and selling snacks and delicacies in her community. She is 44 years old, married and has one grown-up child. She is from the village of Kabacsanan, Iligan City. Marciana has been in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Marciana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Marciana is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.
