About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a food business

loans.name: Laureto

texts.en:
Laureto is a tricycle operator and also a driver. He is 52 years old and married to Perlita, a full-time housewife. For almost 30 years they have also been running a typical retail store in their village. They have one daughter named Karen Pearl, who is 16 years old and a first year college student. They are presently living in baranggay Sta. Maria, Alicia, Isabela – a rural area. Most people living there are into farming. Their house is located along Maharlika Highway.

Laureto's daily net income is 300 up to 500 Philippine pesos (PHP). He desires a loan of 7,000 PHP as additional capital for repair and maintenance of his tricycle. He continuously dreams of increasing their productivity which he wants to achieve in the near future.

loans.use: For repair and maintenance of his motorcycle

loans.name: Marita

texts.en:
Marita C. is from the village of Miputak. She is 54 years old. Marita is married and has 7 children. Five of them are adults and the remaining two are school-aged. To make a living, Marita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Marita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP on average per month for these activities.

In 2006, Marita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Marita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Marita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Galust

texts.en:
41-year-old Galust S. lives in Ddmashen village, near Sevan, with his wife and 3 children. His elder daughter studies at Humanitarian University, and the younger one is a schoolgirl. His 16-year-old son is in his last year of school, and helps his father with his business. 

Galust is a motor mechanic who has had his own garage for 20 years. He buys crushed cars, then repairs and sells them. He currently needs a loan of 600,000 AMD to buy a crushed car. With the income he will make from fixing and selling it, Galust intends to pay for his younger daughter’s education.

loans.use: to buy a crushed car

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Mr. Seng K., 51 years old, is pictured above with his wife. They reside in Pursat Province, Cambodia. This older couple earns a living by cultivating rice and raising pigs as well. They are also the good parents of eight children. Three of the children are married and live separately; the others are single, either employed or students.

Seng K. is taking out his first loan to purchase a boat that he will use for fishing activities. This loan will provide his family with extra income and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a boat that he will use for fishing activities

loans.name: Prum

texts.en:
Prum E., 34, lives in the province of Pursat, Cambodia, where she owns a plot of land next to her house, growing both rice and vegetables. She can plant her crops twice a year, and she was taught this by her grandfather.

Besides her farm work, she raises pigs and also takes time to catch fish with her husband for extra revenue. She is currently a good mother of two school-aged children.

Prum E. will be using her first loan to purchase a cow which she will use to help reduce her hard labor in the farming business.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for agricultural purposes

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia L. is 43 years old, and she is married to Wilson L. who works as a carpenter within their village. They have been blessed with six children: Dina-20 years old who just finished high school; Wilmar-17 years old; Wilson Jr.-15 years old, an elementary pupil; Willie-12 years old; Widdie-five years old, and Christian-three years old. They are happily living in the village of Quezon, San Isidro.

Delia sells "Cindy’s breads" and other kinds of snacks in their village. She would like to buy additional bread so that she could generate bigger income. In this regard, she is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 5,000. She says she is able to generate PHP 1,500 weekly. With this income she still needs to seek additional capital for her to support her children in their schooling. She hopes that she will be given the loan by the KIVA lenders so she can achieve her goals in life.

loans.use: additional capital to buy more bread to sell

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona T. is from the village of Hinaplanan, Iligan City. She is 38 years old. Chona is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Chona owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling electronic load (for all cellphone networks) in the local community. Chona has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Chona joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Chona is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory to sell. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Chona from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of cloth and tailoring accessories

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en: Chhun N. is 53 years old and a resident of Pursat Province, where she has owned a plot of land since 1979. She and her husband grow rice crops, which they plant twice a year. In addition, this couple always takes time to fish. From their business, they can make an average of $5 a day toward managing their family's financial crisis. Because catching fish is a main income source for family, and to help support for this business, Chhun N. is looking for a loan to buy a machine to connect to her existing boat that she will use for fishing.

loans.use: Fishing equipment

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer Q. is a village store owner. She is married to Noel, who cultivates their small farm lot by planting rice and some vegetables. Due to the high cost of commodities, Jennifer wants to acquire more products, but she cannot do so because she lacks business capital. In this regard, she wants to borrow additional capital from Kiva lenders amounting to 5,000 PHP. She will use the money to purchase more goods to sell. She believes that this loan will enable her to improve her small store and earn a higher income.

Jennifer is 22 years old and resides in a peaceful village in Barangay Baculud Iguig, Cagayan. She has only one child to support. She sacrifices her time to support the needs of her child, especially in providing their family's basic needs.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Saifurhman

texts.en:
Saifurhman F. lives in Jalalabad city. He is 21 years old, single, and lives with 8 members of his family. He has a video and CD shop in Jalalabad city and is responsible for paying all of the household expenses.

He has requested an individual loan of 50000 AFN to expand his business and buy more CDs for his shop. He is very happy about the small loan process in Jalalabad, Afghanistan. He wants to continue his partnership with both KIVA and AFS and would like to thank all lenders from around the world.

loans.use: To increase stock.

loans.name: Rey

texts.en:
Rey S. is from the village of Bitibut, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. He is 28 years old and single. Rey owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized a "sari-sari" retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, sugar, candies,salt,soap & toothpaste in the local community.  Rey has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rey joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rey is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rey from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ly's Group

texts.en:
Ly Thị Tạ was born in 1958. She lives with her husband and two sons in Hoi Phu, Dong Hoi, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. Both of them have jobs as builders. She is also a farmer and makes bamboo brooms to sell. She has a monthly income of about 5,000 VND. She is a group leader. She has had loans from Microfund organization for three years and repaid on time. This time, she wants to borrow 4,578 VND ($255) to buy bamboo to make brooms.

There are four other Fund participants in her group:

Bich T. C. was born in 1974. She has three children. She sells chicken in the market. She wants to borrow  4,142 VND ($230) to buy more chicken to sell.

Hong T. K. N. was born in 1974. She has two children. She has a store and wants to borrow 4,142 VND ($230) to expand her store.

Ly T. C. was born in 1966. She has three children. She makes brooms to sell and wants to borrow 5,014 VND ($280) to buy bamboo.

Thoa T. N.  was born in 1977 She has two children. She wants to borrow 5,014 VND ($280 to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bamboo for broom making

loans.name: Jelie

texts.en:
Jelie D. C. is 44 years old and married to Alfredo D. C.. They are blessed with three children named Edelfa, Geoffrey, and Alfredo, Jr. Jelie's husband is tiring of doing field activities. Her children are close to adult age; her eldest child is taking his studies but Jelie does not have enough money to send her children to school. Jelie is a direct seller of Avon products, her only source of income in their village of Marcos, Roxas, Isabela. Her business is not easy because it requires looking for new customers to buy the products that she is selling.

Jelie walks around her village to look for her customers to buy what she is selling. Her business requires her to visit Avon, the company, if her customers have orders. She incurs expenses in fares, because when her customers have orders she needs to go to the company. She does not have enough capital to get an inventory of Avon products to decrease her fare expenses. She wants to borrow the amount of 5,000 PHP for additional capital of her business.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Mirabel

texts.en:
Though Mirabel is married and has two children, she is not living with her husband under the same roof. She lives in Mile 2 Nkwen, Cameroon, with her entire family, in a house with 5 rooms.

Mirabel has had to overcome some challenges in life, including ill health and the death of her father. Since she has been separated from her husband, she has had to take care of her children and pay their school fees alone.

She sells food and drink. She plans to use this loan to buy drinks, crates, pots, dishes, groundnuts, and plantains.

This will be Mirabel's fifth time receiving a loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2003 and has been quite successful in the past with her business due to its location and her reasonable prices. Also, due to her experience, she is now having good profits from her business.

Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children, buy necessities for the family, and provide good medication for them whenever they are sick. She will invest the rest back into her business.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying drinks, crates, pots, dishes, groundnuts, and plantains

loans.name: Anh's Group

texts.en:
D. Anh N. is 48 years old. She lives in Xom Thuong, Uy No, Dong Anh, Ha Noi with her child. She is a clerical staff employee at a school. Besides that, she also breeds pigs and poultry. She has received loans from Microfund organizations for five years and repaid on time. She also works hard to look after her child. She needs a loan to expand her breeding business. This time, she wants to borrow 6,322 VND ($350) to buy food for pigs and poultry.

There are four other Fund participants in her group:

Ngoc T. H. is 44 years old. She wants to borrow 6,322 VND ($350) to raise chickens.

Xuyen T. H. is 43 years old. She wants to borrow 4,142 VND ($230) to breed pigs.

Le T. V. is 55 years old. She breeds fish. She wants to borrow 6,758 VND ($375) to expand her business.

Hoa T. H. is 44 years old. She sells beef in the market. She wants to borrow 8,066 VND ($450) to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy food for pigs and poultry

loans.name: Mrs. Thary Peth Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of sixteen people, is located I. Troeung TroE. village I. Kandal province and each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Thary P. is the village bank president.

Mrs. Thary P. is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. On this plantation she faces an obstacle because her field has infertile soil. I. order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizers to support the rice field.

Mrs. Thary P. is 30 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attending the local school and the youngest one is just 2 years old. Her husband, Mr. Phun Thea, is a blacksmith.

Mrs. SarI. Ut who is a group guarantor is also presented I. the picture with the village bank members.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizers to support her rice field

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a resident of Santiago, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She is 25 years old and she operates a general store. She has two children named Marvin and Princess. Marvin is in Grade I, while Princess is in nursery school. Evelyn's husband, Bobby, is 35 years old and works as a farmer in their village. Evelyn has operated her business since she has been married, but there are times that they closed the store because of lack of capital.

Evelyn would like to borrow 5,000 PHP from Kiva lenders to have additional capital for her store. The capital that she wants to borrow will be used to buy some goods that she has never tried to sell in her store. She will have more income if she adds more goods in her store.

loans.use: To increase inventory and variety of goods

loans.name: Khon

texts.en:
Khon C., 39 and his wife, Sambo Mut, 30, (pictured) live along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2006, and have two children. Unfortunately, one of their children died. Sambo's sister and father live with them.

Khon has been a locksmith and has repaired watches for ten years. His wife stays at home and does housework. He is requesting his first loan of $700 to purchase materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for his locksmith and watch repairing business

loans.name: Mrs. Chann Sim Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty one people who are all living in Troeuy Troeng village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan. They will each use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Chann S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

Mrs. Chann S. is farmer who owns a 2-hectare (5-acre) field on which she cultivates rice. On this plantation she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to buy rice seed. In order to solve this problem, she decided to ask for a loan.

Her husband, Mr. S. Sal, is a fisherman. This couple has five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is an electrician and the others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed for her rice field

loans.name: Mrs. Tha Dou Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of nine people who all live in TroeU. Troeng village in Kandal province. Mrs. Tha D. is the village bank president; she was selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land and earns a living by cultivating rice. However, she faces obstacles on her plantation because she does not have enough money to cultivate rice. Thus, she is asking for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Kong San, is a security guard. Mrs. Tha D. is 48 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another is a blacksmith, three are attending the local school and the youngest is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, fertilizers, pesticides for her farming.

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Sheila B. is from the village of Southern Pob., Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Sheila is single and has two children. To make a living, Sheila owns and operates a specialized "sari-sari" retail store, selling retail products like such as soap, salt, sugar, noodles and other daily use products. Sheila has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Sheila joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sheila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Sheila is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Sheila from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sakhorn

texts.en:
Sakhorn S., 57, and her husband, Thai Hong, 62, were married in 1970. They have nine children: six sons and three daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside of the family home, two work in a garment factory, two have full-time employment and another one is in school. The family lives along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sakhorn and her husband are farmers. They grow rice and lotuses on their own farmland in the village. Sakhorn is requesting a loan of $500 to use for her rice and lotus farm.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth A. is from the village of  Tambo, Ilian City. She is 50 years old. Ruth is married and has one child. To make a living, Ruth owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Ruth has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Ruth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Ruth is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Ruth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Bek

texts.en:
Bek Y. is 55 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. To earn a living, Bek Y. rents a small shop in the market, where she sells bread and soft drinks for income. She sells to her customers who come to buy anything in the market. Bek Y. has four children; one of whom is married and the others are students and also help her in the business when they are not studying. Her husband, Chhil Seam, helps with family responsibilities by growing crop, as well as raising cattle. 

Bek Y. is applying for a loan to use for many purposes. She will buy a machine to squeeze cane trees for sugar cane juice, buy more ingredients for making bread, and, with the rest of the loan, she will begin growing crops.

loans.use: To buy juicing equipment, ingredients for breadmaking and to grow crops

loans.name: Ghada

texts.en:
Ghada is 40 years old and married with three children. She lives in Hebron City, Palestine. She has a poultry business. Her husband has regular work, so they are able to pay their daily expenses. But Ghada wants to earn more; she wants to have her own income and that is why she is requesting a loan of $2,000 to increase the size of her business by buying more chickens for fattening and reselling. 

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband of entrepreneur. In Palestine, it is culturally unacceptable to some people to post a picture of a woman to the internet. However, the loan is to a female entrepreneur.

loans.use: Buying more chickens for fattening and reselling

loans.name: Hong

texts.en:
Hong S., 39, is married with four children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children. To make a living, she is raising pigs and has a business of buying recycling materials, earning approximately an income of $5 USD per day. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. Her husband is involved completely in the recycling business, earning an income of $7 USD per day to help cover the family expenses.

Mrs. S. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of $1,000 USD to buy a plot of farmland, animal food, and recycling materials.

loans.use: Buy a plot of farmland, animal food, and recycling materials

loans.name: Jonard

texts.en:
Jonard M. is from the village of D'ban, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. He is 35 years old and married and with a baby. To make a living, Jonard owns and operates a motorcycle transport business, providing transportation in the local community. Jonard has been in business for over ten years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jonard joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jonard has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and accessories . Jonard is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which also will be used to purchase tires and accessories. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jonard from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to meet his family's daily needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and accessories

loans.name: Chey

texts.en:
Chey S., 52, pictured with her husband, is married and lives with two children in Takeo province. Her husband sells rice noodles to earn a living of US$1.60 per day.

Chey S. is a professional decorator. Since 2000, she has been using beads and other materials to make flower designs on women’s clothes to earn a living and typically makes US$4 each day.

A decorated dress is a kind of Khmer traditional dress and people wear them during Water Festival, P’chum Ben or Khmer New Year. It takes around 7-10 days to complete each dress and so they are expensive. However, most of the people prefer handmade rather than machine made. Chey S. said she learned how to decorate from her mother and she started doing this business since before she was married.

Chey S. would like a loan of US$800 to purchase more silk for her decorating business.

loans.use: To purchase more silk for her decorating business

loans.name: Nita

texts.en: Nita B. is from the village of Del Carmen, Iligan City. She is 60 years old, is widowed, and has two adult children. Nita owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Nita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Nita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 5th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Rem

texts.en: Rem H. raises crops and rice to make a living. She earns approximately $2.66 US per day. She is 53 years old and married. Her husband is employed in a non-governmental organization as a deminer in Preah Vihear Province, earning $5 US per day to help cover the family expenses. Rem H. lives in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children. This is her first loan from Kiva’s partner, CREDIT. Mrs. H. is asking for a loan of $500 US to build a suitable tomb for her ancestors.

loans.use: To build a tomb for her ancestors

loans.name: Aleja

texts.en:
Aleja T. is a 69-year-old self-supporting woman and a wonderful grandmother to her grandchildren. At her age, a vision of giving herself things she didn’t have in her earlier years, as well as being a financial support to her child in raising her grandchildren, inspire her to grow her business. She wants to increase her store's earnings for her vision to come true; thus, she has requested a loan through ASHI.

Throughout Aleja’s membership in ASHI, she has proven her integrity by paying back on time and keeping her business in existence. Moreover, she wants her membership to last while she lives, and until her dreams are reached, not only for herself, but also for the rest of her group mates and co-members in the ASHI center. She wants to set an example to other women, that with loans through MFIs, poverty can possibly be abolished if a person is determined and persistent in achieving their dreams in life.

loans.use: To increase inventory of goods in her variety store

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en:
Mr. Noeun C. assists his wife selling fruit. They buy fruit from Derm Kor market in Phnom Penh for resale in front of a garment factory near their village. Noeun wants to create another business driving a remoque taxi (a motorbike connected to a trailer at the back). He will be able to earn more income to support his family. Hence, Noeun is requesting a loan of $1,200 US to buy a motorbike and a trailer for launching this business.

Noeun, 39, and his wife, Mrs. Chantha Sien, 40, have been married since 1990 and have five children: one son and four daughters. The eldest daughter works in garment factory and the other four children are in school. They live in a small village along National Road No. 5, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mr. Noeun C. is not in the photo; his wife was available instead.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a trailer to drive as a remoque taxi

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Thoeun S. works in a grocery store, making around $7 US each day. She is 41 years old, married and lives with her child in Takeo province. Her husband works as a construction worker building houses. Her husband makes about $3 US each day; however, they must also support an old mother at home. Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also been a factor in making the price of rice very high.

Thoeun S. is asking for a loan of $1200 US to stock grocery items to meet her customers' demands. She is confident that this will be a good business venture, and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

Thoeun S. is in the photo with her husband.

loans.use: To restock a grocery

loans.name: Hang

texts.en: Mr. Hang P. is a 29-year-old married man and father. He works as an electrician for a hotel in the middle of Siem Reap Province. Another source of income for the family comes from his wife’s poultry business. This couple is blessed with three children who are enrolled in school. Hang P. finds it hard to travel to his workplace because he doesn’t have a vehicle. Therefore, Hang P. would like to request a loan to add to his small personal savings in order to buy a used motorcycle for commuting.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle for commuting

loans.name: So

texts.en:
So R. is asking for a loan of $1000 US for a motorbike with a compartment attached for one of her sons to operate as a tuk-tuk driver. She is 55 years old and married. She lives in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband (in the photo) and children. To make a living, she raises crops and rice, earning approximately $1.25 US per day. Her husband is a skillful fisherman. He fishes at the lakes in his village with Cambodian traditional fishing traps. He earns $1.50 US per day to help cover the family expenses. 
Mrs. R. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. This is her first loan from Kiva’s partner, CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike with a compartment attached

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok T. is 30 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a professional tailor in the village who is able to make a living of $3.30 per day, while her husband is a blacksmith. He typically makes about $4.30 each day. This couple has five children, three of whom are in school and one is a garment-factory worker. 

Sok T. would like a loan of $800 for her husband to purchase blacksmith tools.

loans.use: To purchase blacksmith tools

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes S. is from the village of Kiwalan, Iligan City. She is 43 years old. Lourdes is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lourdes operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling "longganiza" (ground pork wrapped with pork skin) in the local community. Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lourdes joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lourdes is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Lourdes from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en: Nhem K., 35, is married. She resides in the Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children. To make a living, she is engaged in a business buying bananas from the local farmers in her village for resale, earning an income of approximately $16 per day. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. Her husband is involved completely in the agriculture sector as a rice farmer, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Mrs. K. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, K. is asking for a loan of $500 to buy a motorbike to transport bananas for sale.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita S., 52 years of age, is a woman who aspires to develop her relationships with other people by running a business. Aside from improving herself, she also wishes to improve her family’s standard of living. She requested a loan, and is willing to bear the responsibility of paying back weekly, in order to sustain her businesses selling vegetables and banig (a native mat made of woven palm tree leaves).

Carmelita has learned to let go of her fears and insecurities, especially in getting her loan and facing the challenges to fulfill her dreams, which anchor on the success of her business. She makes herself strong to face the challenge of dealing with the different personalities of her customers in her everyday business transactions.

Being the sole provider for her family of five children – no matter how hard it may seem sometimes – Carmelita has learned how to be patient and manage to be calm for the sake of good relationships.

loans.use: To purchase large volumes of vegetables and "banig" (native mats)  to sell

loans.name: Chuy

texts.en:
Chuy S., 37, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She makes and sells cow bells in her village, earning approximately $5 US each day. Her husband is a construction worker. On average, he makes about $16 US per day. This couple has three children: one is in school and the other two are too young to attend school. 
Chuy S. is asking for a loan of $1000  US to purchase more construction tools.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools.

loans.name: Ry

texts.en:
Ry S. is asking for a loan of $300 US to purchase a motorbike for one of her family members to travel to work in town. She is 44 years old and married with a school-age child. She lives in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and child. To make a living, she sells porridge and gasoline, earning approximately  $2 US per day. Her husband spends his whole time as a rice field farmer, earning $1.66 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. 
Mrs. S. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. This is her first loan from Kiva’s partner, CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en: Chhun C., 36, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She makes and sells cow bells in the village to earn approximately $2 of profit each day, while her husband is a moto-taxi driver. On average, he makes about $9 in revenue per day. This couple has four children, two in school and two yet too young to attend. Chhun C. is asking for a loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike to operate a moto-taxi business.

loans.use: To operate a moto-taxi business.

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mr. Saroeun K., 34, and his wife, Mrs. Sopha Chan, 32, have been growing vegetables for three years. In addition, they have been renting musical instruments for one year. They were married in 2004 and have two sons: one attends school and the other one is still too young. They live along National Road No. 1 about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Saroeun Saroeun is now requesting his first loan of $500 to purchase a generator for his business.
Saroeun is in the photo with his wife.

loans.use: To purchase a generator

loans.name: Khoem

texts.en: Khoem V. is 42 years old and lives in Siem Reap Province. Khoem V. earns a living by raising some poultry from her home. She raises it for both slaughtering and for chicks. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver. The family has been building their house for months, but their new house is not finished since they don't money. Therefore, Khoem V. has decided to seek a loan on Kiva through HKL to be used to finish building her new house.

loans.use: To finish building her new house

loans.name: Abdul Karim

texts.en:
This is A. K., son of A. Rahim. He is a 34-year-old married father of three sons and one daughter. He is living with his whole family, including his father and mother, in the Behsood district.

When he found information about AFS (Ariana Financial Services Joint Stock Company), he requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani to expand his business. He has a butcher shop in the city of Jalalabad and he wants to supports his family.

loans.use: To buy animals for his butcher shop

loans.name: Morita

texts.en: Morita V. is a member of ASHI, a Kiva partner, who is requesting a loan that will be used to grow her hog-fattening (pig-raising) and rice-production (rice-farming) businesses.  Proceeds of the said businesses will be a great source of income for her to be able to support her two dependent children, who are 22 and 27, as well as her grandchildren. Being the sole provider for her two children who are college undergraduates, Morita is dependent on her loan for financing the growth of her business since her daily profit can only be spent for their food and other basic needs. With her continuous membership in ASHI, Morita hoped to access more loans, which will make her business successful and sustainable. By then, her confidence might be developed and her family’s way of living will be improved.

loans.use: To purchase necessary farm inputs for rice planting and to purchase piglets and feed

loans.name: Horl

texts.en: Horl T. is 37 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. Since 2000, she has been making and selling religious tools at the local market to earn a living.  She is able to make about $5 each day, while her husband is a construction worker who is able to make $3.30 every day. This couple has eight children, five of whom are in school and two are employed as garment-factory workers. Horl T. is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase materials to make religious tools.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make religious tools

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie D. is from the village of D'BAN Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old. Elvie is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Elvie makes and sells food in the local community. Elvie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

Elvie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business so she can improve her family's living situation. Elvie is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP that she will use to purchase additional equipment for making food. This is Elvie's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template to allow the Field Partners to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional equipment for making food

loans.name: Prom

texts.en:
Prom S., 28, is married and has one child. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia with her husband and child. To make a living, she raises pigs, grows rice, and sells fish, earning approximately US $1.75 per day. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. 

Her husband is a skillful fisherman. He goes fishing every day in the lake in his village. He uses traditional Cambodian fishing traps, earning an income of US $3 per day to help cover the family's expenses. When he is not fishing, he helps his wife in the field. Mrs. S. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase more fishing tools for her husband to expand his work.

loans.use: Buy fishing supplies

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie Sanggat is an outspoken yet soft-hearted woman. Since she was young, Tessie was fond of cultivating the land for farming the way Mother Nature takes care of its resources. Planting rice, vegetables, and root crops were her family’s source of living then. When Tessie had her own family, this same activity became her source of income to support the needs of her four children who are now 19 to 25 years old. After many years of doing such business, her family's standard of living has changed very little because all the profit she and her husband make farming is barely sufficient to cover her family's basic needs.

By becoming a member of ASHI and through the loan she can access, Tessie thinks that the livelihood activity she and her husband are doing will become a business someday and through cultivating the land she will also be cultivating her own potential as well as her children’s potentials despite of their low educational attainment. She will used the loan to purchase rice seed, peanuts, and string beans seedlings for her farming business.

loans.use: To purchase rice, peanut, and string beans seedlings

loans.name: Chhen

texts.en: Chhen S., 55, is married and has one child. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia with her husband and child. To make a living, she grows rice and also buys recycling materials. She earns approximately US $3 per day. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. Her husband is involved completely in the recycling business, earning an income of US $4 per day to help cover the family expenses. Mrs. S. and her family are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to transport recyclable materials.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S., 42, is married and lives with six of her children in the Takeo province. Since 2005, she has been using beads and other materials to make flowers on women's clothing to earn a living. Typically, she makes US$3 each day. She decorates a kind of Khmer traditional dress that people wear for special events such as Water Festival, Pchum Ben, or Khmer New Year. It takes around 7-10 days to complete each dress and its price is expensive too. Most of the people prefer handmade rather than machine-made clothing. She said she learned how to decorate from her mother and she started doing this business before she was married. Her husband is a construction worker and farmer who earns about US$2 per day. Kong S. would like a loan of US$800 so her husband can purchase cows to assist with the farm work.

loans.use: To purchase cows.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey H., age 52, lives in Siem Reap. She usually buys various products at the cheapest price from her wholesale supplier and then resells them in the local market to gain a profit. She sells items such as pork, beef, and some vegetables. From her business, she typically makes around $3 each day to manage her family's daily expenses. 

She is a widow blessed with four children: three are employed in different jobs, while the other one attends school. One of her sons, who is pictured, is a motorbike taxi driver. Srey H. said that her son's business has also been interrupted because his motorbike often breaks down. Because of this problem, Srey H. has decided to seek a loan to replace the old motorbike.

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Un C., 27, makes a living by buying recyclable materials for resale, earning approximately $2 US per day. She is married with a young child. She lives in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband (pictured) and child. Her husband works full-time in the recycling business, earning $4 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. 
Mrs. C. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, C. is asking for a loan of $600 US to purchase a motorbike to transport the recyclable materials to sell them more easily. This is her first loan from Kiva’s partner, CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng S. is 23 years old and resides with her husband and one young child in Takeo province. She and her husband make and sell piggy banks to earn a living and are able to make about US$2 profit each day. To earn additional income, Seng S. would like to take out a loan of US$700 to raise pigs.

loans.use: To raise pigs.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: 43-year-old Jocelyn D. wants to grow her hog fattening (pig raising) and variety store business to support the financial needs of her four children. They range in age from eight to 16 years old.  Aside from providing her family with their basic needs every day, she hopes to send her children to college through graduation so they have more opportunities for a better kind of life in the future. All of these aspirations will only happen once her business grows and she has bigger profits since her husband’s income is very small and sporadic. It is through ASHI and through loans she accesses then and now that she gains the strength to be consistent in surmounting the obstacles she encounters every day in her business to bring her family out of poverty.

loans.use: To increase inventory in her variety store and purchase piglets and feed.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn F. is from the village of Bocator Tangub City. She is 33 years old. Marilyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn sells cloth ready to wear products in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marilyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marilyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and for daily expenses. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Moul

texts.en: Moul K., 40, is married with four school-aged children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia with her husband and children. To make a living, she sells fish and vegetables at the market, earning approximately US $5 per day. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. Her husband is a middleman, buying cows from the local farmers in the village and selling them to the markets in town, earning an income of US $10 per day to help cover the family expenses. Mrs. K. and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, K. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase cows, fish, and vegetables to expand the current business.

loans.use: To buy cows, fish and vegetables

loans.name: Suos

texts.en: Suos S., 36, is married and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a professional handicrafts decorator. Since 2000, she has been using beads and other materials to make flowers on women's clothes to earn a living. She typically makes US$3 each day. A decorated dress is a kind of Khmer traditional dress and people wear it during Water Festival, P’chum Ben or Khmer New Year. It takes around 7-10 days to complete each dress and its price is expensive too. Most of the people prefer hand made to machine made. She said she learned how to decorate from her mother and she has started doing this business before she was married. Her husband is a farmer who earns a living of US$2 per day. Suos S. would like a loan of US$800 to purchase silk, beads and other materials to make more clothes.

loans.use: To purchase silk, beads and other materials to make more clothes.

loans.name: Nary

texts.en:
Mrs. Nary S., age 28 (shown in the picture with her husband) and her husband, Mr. Sopheap So, age 29, have been married since 2003 and have two children. Both of them are still young and have not yet started their education. They live in a small village on National Road number 2 about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Nary has been a garment factory worker for seven years, while her husband has been a driver for a company for three years. By the way, the couple is in the process of building a new house, but they lack some money to finish it. Therefore, Nary is requesting her first loan of $1,000 in order to finish  the house.

loans.use: To finish building her house.

loans.name: Creselda

texts.en:
Creselda D. is from the village of Kiwalan Iligan City. She is 43 years old. Creselda is widowed and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Creselda sells specialty food products in the local community. Creselda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Creselda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Creselda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Creselda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Creselda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Botte Women's Group Jinja

texts.en: Harriet K. is a 45-year-old widow who cares for her four children. She is the leader of her group in Jinja. Harriet has been buying and selling produce in the town center for seven years and generates 100,000 USH profit/week from this activity. She is very hardworking and hopes to be able to continue providing for her family’s needs, especially their education.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Un

texts.en: Mr. Un C., age 53, makes a living driving a taxi trailer-motorcycle, picking up his passengers in and around his community for fees. He currently earns an average of $3 a day and has been running his business for years. Beside this, he raises poultry in a stall next to his house for extra profit. Un C. is the father of three school-aged children. His wife sells a few grocery items to earn a living. She is also a good housewife who cooks delicious meals. Un C. requested a loan to help increase his wife's business capital and buy more feed for his poultry.

loans.use: As business capital for his wife and to buy poultry feed

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en: Teopista is a 50-year-old single mother of four children between the ages of 5 and 20 years .All her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she stays with seven people. Teopista takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets two meals a day. She doesn’t incur additional transport to and from shopping because she buys from people who get it in the  villages. She has a small bar selling all types of beer and local gin and sells to all categories of people both at retail and at wholesale. Teopista works seven days a week .She receives an average of 30 customers a day. Her major business challenges include thieves and the rainy season, which hinders her customers from coming to her because she works in a muddy place. Teopista‘s monthly expenses includes school fees, rent for her business premises and residence and feeding the family. She has been in this business for 15 years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her 12th loan working with the same group mates. Teopista joined MCDT because it was near her home and also she wanted to increase her capital. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of local gin and crates of beer. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start selling at wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Orm

texts.en:
Orm C., 39, is married and lives with four of her children in the Takeo province. She is a professional handicraft decorator. Since 2005, she has been using beads and other materials to make flowers on women's clothes to earn a living, typically making $3 each day. Decorated dresses are a kind of Khmer traditional dress people wear during the Water Festival, P’chum Ben or Khmer New Year. It takes around 7 to 10 days to complete each dress and its price is expensive too. Most people prefer handmade over machine made. She said she knows how to decorate from her mother and she started doing this business before she was married. 

Her husband is a taxi driver who earns $3 per day as well. Orm C. would like a loan of $800 as her husband needs to fix his taxi car.

loans.use: Fix taxi

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios A. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 58 years old. Remedios is widowed and has three adult children. To make a living, Remedios raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

Remedios joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional pigs to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Remedios from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional pigs to sell

loans.name: Lim

texts.en:
Mr. Lim V., age 35, makes a living driving a taxi motorcycle, picking up his passengers in and around his community. He currently earns an average of $4.50 a day and has been running his service at least five years. Lim V. is the father of two children, both of whom are teenagers and attend school. His wife, Sok Pheak, raises pigs and sells some groceries from home. 

Lim V. requests a loan of $500 for his wife to purchase more piglets to raise, as well as buying more groceries for sale.

loans.use: To purchase more piglet to raise, as well as buying more groceries for sale

loans.name: Set

texts.en:
Mr. Set S., age 25, and his wife, Mrs. Chiva Noem, age 24, have been married since 2006 and have a young daughter. The family lives along National Road Number One, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh.
 
Set has been a chef for 8 years; his wife stays at home. Because Set's business is the family's only source of income is only from his business, Set wants his wife to raise pigs at home. It will help them to generate income to support their family. Therefore, Set is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to build a pigpen and purchase piglets for his wife to raise.

loans.use: To build a pigpen and buy piglets.

loans.name: Hafiza

texts.en:
The girl who is pictured is Hafiza, the daughter of H. A.. She is a young girl of 22, single, living in a family of 7 members. She has a beauty salon where she works hard. She has worked here for more than 5 years.

After graduation from school she decided to work, and started as a beautician. She started her work with few materials, only a small amount of cosmetics and some chairs. Then, she wanted to expand her business, so when she received information from one of her neighbors about the process of small loans, she came to AFS and requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani to purchase new and well-designed cosmetics to attract more clients. She would like to mention that Kiva is an effective process which can support all entrepreneurs.

loans.use: purchasing cosmetics and the other necessary materials

loans.name: Suos

texts.en:
Suos S. is 61 years old. She lives in Takeo Province with five of her children and her husband. To earn a living, she sells porridge and weaves silk clothes that she sells in the local market. She is able to make about US $3.00 every day. Her husband is a pump pipe worker. On average, he also makes US $3.00 per day. This couple is also supported by four of their children who are garment factory workers and waiters. 

Suos S. would like a loan of US $1000 to purchase more silk to weave silk clothes.

loans.use: To purchase more silk.

loans.name: Sreyra

texts.en:
Miss Sreyra P., age 22, is single and lives with her parents along National Road Number One, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has four siblings. 

Sreyra was not available for a photo because she was busy with her work, so her mother appears in the photo instead.

Sreyra has a full-time job in Phnom Penh and she has to spend a lot of money for traveling costs. It’s expensive for the family, so she is applying for her first loan of $1,000 to buy a motorcycle to commute to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to commute to work

loans.name: Mukwano Development Group Of Jinja

texts.en:
Dorica A. is 22 years old and the leader of her loan group in Jinja. She is married and has a two-year-old child. She also cares for two orphans. 

For two years, Dorica has been running a clothing boutique and has experienced tremendous success in the enterprise. She would like a loan of 300,000 USH to keep up with the high level of demand for her products. She hopes that her business will continue to grow and that she will be able to continue providing for her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her clothing boutique

loans.name: Nol

texts.en: Nol M., age 56, is a widow who lives in Takeo Province with her four children. She works as a farmer and is typically able to make US $3.00 each day. She is aided by her three children who are garment factory workers. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has been out of control. These factors have created a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, made worse because food prices have also been high. Nol M. is asking for US $600 to raise cows.

loans.use: To buy cows to raise

loans.name: Verginia

texts.en:
Verginia E. is from the village of Pangabuan Tangub City. She is 45 years old. Verginia is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Verginia owns & operates a specialized retail store selling daily use products and dried goods products in the local community. Verginia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Verginia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Verginia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Verginia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and to pay for daily needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: 06.1.3 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Tư P. Thị (13) is a 45-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá.  Tư is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 02.6.1.3 (02.6.1.3 Nam Ngạn).


Tư is married and has one infant child.  To making a living, Tư sells rice products in the local community.  Tư has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 3.000.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007, Tư joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Tư has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3.079.800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Tư from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Tư plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  N. Thị Diệu (15) is a 52-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business making & selling food.


2.  N. Thị Lanh (17) is a 26-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business operating a specialized retail store.


3.  Ngô Thị Phú (16) is a 51-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business making & selling food.


4.  P. Thị Đông (14) is a 57-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business making & selling food.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Tư P. Thị (13) là 45 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Tư là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 02.6.1.3 (02.6.1.3 Nam Ngạn).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ gạo trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Tư thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 30 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Tư kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2007, Tư đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Tư đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. Thị Diệu (15) là 52 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


2.  N. Thị Lanh (17) là 26 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


3.  Ngô Thị Phú (16) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


4.  P. Thị Đông (14) là 57 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Ny A. is 43 years old. She lives with her husband in Takeo Province. Since 2008, she has been selling fried bananas to earn a living. She is able to make about US $4.00 each day. Her husband sells yams at the local market and makes an average of US $13 in revenue each day. 

Ny A. would like a loan of US $600 to buy her husband a motorbike. He will use the motorbike to transport yams to the market to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport yams

loans.name: Seab

texts.en:
Fishing is the most important part of 25-year-old Seab S.’s daily work. She and her husband have been living on a fishing boat on the river for more than nine years. This couple wake up every morning, drives their boat toward the middle of the river, and then fishes. After the fishing is done, they hurry to bring their fish to the market and sell to their regular buyers on credit. They collect their money after their buyers sell all of the fish that they bought. 

Seab S. and her husband also support their two children who are enrolled in school. Seab S. is not comfortable, because her house often needs to be repaired. She would like a loan to repair her old house.

loans.use: To repair her old house

loans.name: Sayed Asef

texts.en: Sayed Asef is the son of Mir M. A..  He lives in the 2nd district of Kabul, Afghanistan.  He owns and operates a photography and photocopy shop, and all of his family members benefit from the income he generates. He has been working in his shop for almost 7 years.  He needed a new computer for his shop, and he didn’t have much money for it, so he requested an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani to purchase his computer and other necessary items to expand his business.  He is glad that Kiva loans support entrepreneurs in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To purchase a computer and other items to expand his business

loans.name: Alfreda

texts.en:
Alfreda V. is from the village of Usocan. She is 54 years old. Alfreda is married and has 54 school-aged children. To make a living, Alfreda raises and sells pigs. Alfreda has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Alfreda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alfreda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Alfreda is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be Alfreda 4th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy feed and supllies for her piglets

loans.name: Petrona

texts.en:
Petrona M. is from the village of Misom in Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 58 years old. Petrona is widowed and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Petrona Wilma bakes and sells bread. Petrona has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,800 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Petrona joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Petrona is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional equipment for baking bread. This will be Petrona's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy equipment for baking bread

loans.name: Phann

texts.en: Phann K., age 38, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo Province. To earn a living, she and her husband have been renting musical instruments to the local villagers. On average, they are able to make about US $5.00 of profit every day. This couple has five children, only two of whom are old enough to attend school. Phann K. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to transport the musical instruments.

loans.use: Musical instruments

loans.name: Chanthoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthoeun P., 42, is a widow with one son. She lives on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. Her son has been a construction worker for one year; he is a farmer as well.

Chanthoeun has been a silk weaver for over ten years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. 

Chanthoeun is asking for a loan of $1,200 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business and to help her son by providing capital for his farming business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business and capital for her son's farming business

loans.name: Stella Mae

texts.en:
Stella Mae L. is from the village of Magcamiguing, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 27 years old, is married, and has three infant children. Stella Mae operates a business making and selling food, selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. Stella Mae joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional equipment for food-making. This loan will be her first from GDMPC.
